{{Infobox person |name = Running Rabbit |image = File:Aatsista-Mahkan-LOC.jpg |caption = Chief Running Rabbit photographed by [[Edward S. Curtis]], c. 1900 |nationality = [[Siksika Nation|Siksika (Blackfoot)]]
[[Blackfoot Confederacy]] |lead = |birth_date = c. 1833 |birth_place = [[Rupert's Land]] |death_date = probably 24 January 1911 |death_place = |predecessor = |successor = |native_name = Aatsista-Mahkan |nicknames = |known_for = A chief of the Siksika people |death_cause = |resting_place = |rp_coordinates = |religion = |party = |education = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = Many Swans (father) |relations = Many Swans II (brother) |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Aatsista-Mahkan''' or '''Running Rabbit''' (''[[Circa|c.]]'' 1833 – probably 24 January 1911) was a [[Tribal chief|chief]] of the [[Siksika Nation|Siksika]] [[First Nation]]. He was the son of [[Akamukai]] (Many Swans), chief of the Biters band, and following the death of his father in 1871, Aatsista-Mahkan took control of the band.[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=7165 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online''] He was known for his generosity and kindness, and for his loyal protection of his family. In 1877, he was a signatory to [[Treaty 7]], but he and his people continued to follow the [[bison]] until 1881, when he and his people were designated to settle on a [[indian reserve|reserve]], 60 miles east of today's [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]]. ==Early life== Running Rabbit was born into a prominent family. His older brother Many Swans, who took their father's name, was chief of Biters band of Siksikas to which they belonged. As a teenager and young warrior, Running Rabbit had not performed any great deeds worthy of recognition until his brother lent him an amulet said to have spiritual powers made from a mirror decorated with eagle feathers, ermine skins, and magpie feathers. Running Rabbit was successful during his first ever raid as a warrior, gaining himself two enemy horses which he captured and gifted to Many Swans. Similar success during following expeditions resulted in Many Swans giving Running Rabbit the amulet as a gift. Word of Running Rabbit's success spread throughout the Biters band and many referred to him as the "young chief" before he earned or was appointed any leadership position in the band. ==Chief of the Biters band== During the autumn of 1871, chief Many Swans, the chief of the Biters band of the Siksika nation and brother of Running Rabbit, died resulting in Running Rabbit being appointed as chief of the biters. During his career as a band chief he was noted for his kindness, generosity and intelligence. {{quote|When Running Rabbit was among his band, his men were invited to eat, smoke, tell stories every day. He was generous. He gave his running horses out during hunts. Running Rabbit had four wives; two put up Sun Dances. He was kind to children and women.|-Descendent of Running Rabbit }} [[File:Running Rabbit - Chief Blackfeet Indians.jpg|thumb|left|Chief Running Rabbit]] Due to his intelligence and kindness, Running Rabbit was often looked upon to settle disputes within the band and nation. One incident happened during the early 1870s along the [[Oldman River]] where a man from the biters band accidentally killed one of [[Crowfoot|Crowfoot's]] daughters with a loaded gun. The man hid from Crowfoot who sought to kill him in retaliation in Running Rabbit's teepee. Running Rabbit stressed to Crowfoot that the killing was an accident and gave Crowfoot some horses as added compensation. Though usually peaceful in settling disputes Running Rabbit resorted to violence when the well being of his family was threatened, a noted incident involved Running Rabbit shooting a fellow Indian for beating his blind brother with a whip. ==Treaty No.7 signing== Running Rabbit signed [[Treaty 7|Treaty No.7]] with the Canadian government alongside other Siksika nation chiefs including Crowfoot and Old Sun. The treaty promised the [[Blackfoot Confederacy]] reserve lands, hunting rights, trapping rights, and annual provisions/and or payments from the Queen in exchange for all of the traditional territory of the confederacy with the exception of lands set aside for reservations. Running Rabbit was recognized as a minor Siksika chief and was listed as having 90 followers. Running Rabbit and his band continued to live a traditional nomadic lifestyle until the last bison herds within the area were destroyed in 1881, resulting in his band and others of the Siksika nation settling on their previously set aside reserve 60 miles east of [[Calgary]] Alberta. On the reservation Running Rabbit was noted for trying to adapt to a new lifestyle which was forced upon them, becoming a noted farmer in 1887. ==Later life and death== In 1892 after the death of head chief No-okska-stumik (Three Bulls), Running Rabbit was appointed as one of the two head chiefs of the Siksika nation alongside fellow chief Old Sun. He remained known for his wisdom, kindness and progressiveness. In 1898 he had made enough money harvesting hay to buy a high top buggy. Running Rabbit died in 1911. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aatsista-Mahkan}} [[Category:Indigenous leaders in Alberta]] [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1911 deaths]] [[Category:Blackfoot people]]

{{use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Alberto Beneduce |image = Alberto Beneduce1.gif |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 29 May 1877 |birth_place =[[Caserta]] |death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1944|4|26|1877|5|29}} |death_place = [[Rome]] |residence = |nationality = [[Italians|Italian]] |alma_mater = |occupation = |years_active = 1900s – 1940 |net_worth = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |children = Idea Nuova Socialista
Italia Libera
Vittoria Proletaria |parents = |signature = |website = }} '''Alberto Beneduce''' (29 May 1877 – 26 April 1944) was an [[Italians|Italian]] politician, scholar and financier, who was among the founders of many significant state-run finance institutions in [[Italy]]. ==Early life and education== Beneduce was born in [[Caserta]] on 29 May 1877.{{cite journal|last=Pitzalis|first=Andrea|title=Il giovane Alberto Beneduce: gli anni della formazione intellettuale tra la politica e le aspirazioni accademiche (1904-1911)|journal=SPE|year=2009|pages=45–76|url=http://www.francoangeli.it/Riviste/Scheda_Rivista.aspx?idArticolo=36547|accessdate=25 April 2013}} He earned a mathematics degree in [[Naples]].{{cite journal|last=Bico |first=Elena |title=Alberto Beneduce |journal=il bolletino |date=March 2012 |volume=11 |issue=10 |url=http://www.generali.com/265333/Bollettino-10-eng.pdf |accessdate=31 May 2013 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Career and views== Beneduce was a [[socialist]].{{cite book|author1=Franco Amatori|author2=Robert Millward|author3=Pier Angelo Angelo Toninelli|title=Reappraising State-Owned Enterprise: A Comparison of the UK and Italy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7hDb-HSw0ycC&pg=PT49|accessdate=31 May 2013|date=23 May 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-73829-6|page=49}} Nevertheless, he managed to connect with high finance figures and to collaborate with the Italy's [[Italy's Fascism|fascist regime]].{{cite book|author=Roland Sarti|title=Italy: A Reference Guide from the Renaissance to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xhoLorFC1iwC&pg=PA148|accessdate=25 April 2013|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-7474-7|page=148}} He served at different posts, including statistician, teacher, demographer, agricultural and insurance specialist. He served as a university professor of statistics and demography until 1919. He contributed to the establishment of the national institution of insurance (INA), which was founded in 1912. He also headed the INA from 1917 to 1919. During [[World War I]], he was asked to established an institution that would help the veterans in finding jobs. As a result, he involved in founding the related body, Opera Nazionale Combettenti (ONC). He was appointed head of two state-run credit bodies: Consorzio di Credito per le Opere Pubbliche ([[Crediop]]) in 1919 and Istituto di Credito per le Opere di Pubblica Utilita (ICIPU) in 1924. Until 1939 he was the head of both institutions. These institutions were later merged under the name of Istituto per il Credito Navale.{{cite book|author1=Manfred Pohl|author2=Sabine Freitag|author3=European Association for Banking History|title=Handbook of the History of European Banks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eXvfNDHpfWwC&pg=PA570|accessdate=25 April 2013|year=1994|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-78195-421-8|page=570}} In 1931, he was named as a board member of the [[Istituto Mobiliare Italiano]]. He also served as the economic advisor to [[Benito Mussolini]].{{cite journal|last=Amatori |first=Franco |author2=Andrea Colli |title=Corporate governance: the Italian story |journal=Targeted Socio-Economic Research |date=December 2000 |url=http://www.insead.edu/v1/projects/cgep/Research/NationalSystems/CGItaly.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924035453/http://www.insead.edu/v1/projects/cgep/Research/NationalSystems/CGItaly.pdf |archivedate=24 September 2015 }} In 1933, he was appointed by Mussolini as the head of the institute for industrial reconstruction (IRI), being the first president of the body. Until 1939 he served as the head of the institution.{{cite journal|last=Giani|first=Leonardo|title=Ownership and control of Italian banks|journal=Corporate Ownership & Control|date=Fall 2008|volume=6|issue=1|pages=87–98|url=http://www.virtusinterpress.org/additional_files/journ_coc/Paper09.pdf|accessdate=25 April 2013}} He became a senator in 1939, but retired from politics and other public offices due to his health problems in 1940. However, he retained his membership on the boards of various companies until his death. ===Activities=== Beneduce and Luigi Rossi recorded detailed statistics about Italian citizens, who had migrated to the US, but returned to Italy between 1905 and 1906.{{cite book|title=From Italy to San Francisco: the immigrant experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ESusAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA49|accessdate=25 April 2013|year=1982|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-1117-3|page=49}} Beneduce was instrumental in the nationalization of life insurance in Italy.{{cite book|author=Richard J. Samuels|title=Machiavelli's Children: Leaders and Their Legacies In Italy And Japan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9kAbOwB9tYQC&pg=PA136|accessdate=25 April 2013|date=19 May 2005|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-8982-2|page=136}} His activities in the finance sector of Italy shaped the industrial development of the country between the 1920s and the 1990s.{{cite book|author1=H. W. De Jong|author2=William G. Shepherd|title=Pioneers of Industrial Organization: How the Economics of Competition and Monopoly Took Shape|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TpfrPPOFWUIC&pg=PA100|accessdate=25 April 2013|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84720-696-1|page=100}} One of his significant activities in this regard was the reorganization of the bankrupted Italian banking system. In addition, he was the mentor of many eminent financiers and technocrats, who reconstructed Italy after [[World War II]]. He also developed Mussolini's [[Deflation|deflation policy]].{{cite web|title=The Depression|url=http://histclo.com/essay/war/dep/cou/ita/dep-ita.html|publisher=Historical Boy's Clothing|accessdate=31 May 2013}} ===Personal life=== Beneduce had three daughters whose names reflected his socialist orientation: Idea Nuova Socialista, Italia Libera, and Vittoria Proletaria.{{citation|title=Die Agnellis: die heimlichen Herrscher Italiens|first=Vito|last=Avantario|publisher=Campus Verlag|year=2002|isbn=9783593369068|page=179|language=German|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dt8no_jKEXUC&pg=PA179}}. One of his daughter, Idea, married [[Enrico Cuccia]], a significant financier.{{cite news|last=Stanley|first=Alessandra|title=Enrico Cuccia Is Dead at 92; Key Figure in Italian Banking|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/24/business/enrico-cuccia-is-dead-at-92-key-figure-in-italian-banking.html|accessdate=25 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=24 June 2000}}{{cite journal|last=Zamagni|first=Vera|title=Governing the Italian economy: a comparative perspective|journal=Journal of Modern Italian Studies|year=2009|volume=14|issue=1|pages=46–51|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13545710802642883|accessdate=26 April 2013|doi=10.1080/13545710802642883}} ==Death== Beneduce died in [[Rome]] on 26 April 1944.{{cite web|title=Alberto Beneduce collection |url=http://www.bancaditalia.it/serv_pubblico/elenco-dei-servizi/biblioteca/patrimonio/fondi_bibliobaffi/fondo_A_beneduce;internal&action=_setlanguage.action?LANGUAGE=en |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130702123314/http://www.bancaditalia.it/serv_pubblico/elenco-dei-servizi/biblioteca/patrimonio/fondi_bibliobaffi/fondo_A_beneduce;internal&action=_setlanguage.action?LANGUAGE=en |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 July 2013 |publisher=Bank of Italy |accessdate=25 April 2013 }} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beneduce, Alberto}} [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:People from Caserta]] [[Category:Italian socialists]] [[Category:Italian statisticians]] [[Category:Italian economists]] [[Category:Italian mathematicians]] [[Category:Leaders of organizations]] [[Category:Members of the Senate of the Kingdom of Italy]]

فنية واعلامية - أريبيان بزنس|website=arabic.arabianbusiness.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}} and [[Music]]ian.{{cite web|url=https://www.emaratalyoum.com/life/four-sides/2018-03-29-1.1084639|title=جديد علي الخوار.. بلهجة بيضاء وصوت العزكي - الإمارات اليوم|website=emaratalyoum.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alapn.co/ar/?p=45586|title=الخوار يشارك بذكرى اليوم الوطني السعودي بقصيدة “عرضة وحربية” – وكالة أنباء الشعر|website=alapn.co|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://alqabas.com/606534/|title="لولو الحب" إهداء إلى الكويت الغالية – القبس الإلكتروني|website=alqabas.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}} ==Bio== Chairman of the Board of Directors of "Audio Company".{{cite web|url=https://www.alroeya.ae/article/291573/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%B2%D9%86-%D8%A3%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%83-%D8%B7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%86%D9%8A|title=منصة الرؤية - الرئيسيةعلي الخوّار لـ "الحزن": "أترجاك طلقني" - منصة الرؤية|website=alroeya.ae|accessdate=2018-11-23}} He wrote poetry at the age of 16, influenced by his father. He wrote more than a hundred songs and a national poem and emotional [[song]]s, most famous «in the heart of your love entrench my country». He participated in more than one Arab Poetry Festival, won the Best [[Arabic]] Text [[Award]] at the Arabic Song Festival in [[Manama]] in 1996.{{cite web|url=https://www.zahratalkhaleej.ae/Article/532950/%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84-%D8%A3%D8%BA%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%AE%D9%84%D9%8A%D8%AC%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF-%D8%B9%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%81-%D8%A8%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%82%D9%8A%D8%B9-%D8%A5%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D9%84%D8%A8%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A|title=زهرة الخليج - أول أغنية خليجية لمحمد عساف بتوقيع إماراتي لبناني|website=zahratalkhaleej.ae|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://www.yasmina.com/%D9%86%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B2/210180-%D9%82%D9%86%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%84%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1|website=yasmina.com|title=قنبلتان نوويتان جديدتان للشاعر علي الخوار|accessdate=2018-11-23}} He also won the title of "Knight" of the UAE song in 1995. He was famous for a number of [[song]]s that were sung by [[Gulf]] and [[Arab]] [[artist]]s, It was sung by the [[artist]] "Mehd Hamad" in the early 1990s. In 2008, he won the second place for the completion of the poem by "Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]]" in the competition of the Ministry of Culture and Youth.{{cite web|url=https://www.albayan.ae/five-senses/dialogue/2016-10-30-1.2747229|title=علي الخوار: فخور بإسهامي في القصيدة الوطنية - البيان|website=albayan.ae|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://rotana.net/tv-articles/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%8A-%D9%82%D8%B5%D8%A9-%D8%A5%D8%B3%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%87-%D9%81%D9%8A/|website=rotana.net|title=الشاعر علي الخوار يروي قصة إسهاماته في تطوير الكلم...|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://ar.nnews.me/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AD%D9%8A%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%83%D8%B1%D9%85-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D9%87%D8%B1/|title=علي الخوار الشاعر الوحيد المكرم في مهرجان ضيافة 2017|website=Nnews|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/1590772|title=جريدة الرياض | "هلوسات" ديوان أول لـ علي الخوار|website=alriyadh.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}} == Career == He worked as a secretary for the editor of "Fajr al-Sha'raa", a literary issue that was published by [[Al Fajr]].{{cite web|url=http://www.akhbarak.net/articles/33859890-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%84-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D8%B7%D9%84%D9%82|title=الإماراتي علي الخوار يطلق قصيدة عرضة وحربية في اليوم الوطني السعودي - فن|website=akhbarak.net|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youm7.com/story/2018/11/21/%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88-%D9%84%D9%88%D9%84%D9%88-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A8-%D8%A3%D8%BA%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%87%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%B3/4039985|title=فيديو.. "لولو الحب" أغنية جديدة لماجد المهندس - اليوم السابع|website=youm7.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}} And the editor of ink and paper editor of '''Al-Wahda newspaper'''. He was the editor of "Shababna magazine", which was issued by the Ministry of Youth and Sports in the UAE. He supervised the poetry section of Buh Al-Qawafi in the magazine of the whole family of UAE from 1996 to 2009. He also supervised the recording and photography of the poems of Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan.{{cite web|url=http://www.jfranews.com.jo/more-150437-20-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%83-%D9%8A%D8%B4%D9%83%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1|title=جفرا نيوز : أخبار الأردن | الملك يشكر الشاعر الإماراتي علي الخوار|website=jfranews.com.jo|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://www.sayidaty.net/node/284716/%D9%81%D9%86-%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D9%8A%D8%B1/%D8%A3%D8%AE%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D9%8A%D8%B1/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D9%83%D8%B4%D9%81-%D8%B9%D9%86-%D8%B9%D9%85%D9%84-%D9%84%D9%81%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8-%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AE%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A2%D8%AE%D8%B1-%D9%84%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%AF#photo/1|title=علي الخوار يكشف عن عمل لفنان العرب ويخفي آخر لراشد الماجد | مجلة سيدتي|website=sayidaty.net|accessdate=2018-11-23}} Currently, he is the owner and general manager of Orange Advertising and Media,{{cite web|url=http://almanara-magazine.com/2016/06/01/%D8%B0%D9%83%D8%B1%D9%89-%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B7%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7/|title=ذكرى ميلاد “شاعر الوطن الاماراتي” علي الخوار | مجلة المنارة|website=almanara-magazine.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://www.layalina.com/%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%B1-%D9%86%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D9%86-%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%8A%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%83%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%87%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%AA-2020-248387.html|title=صور نجوم الفن والاعلام يشاركون على الخوار في اصدار ديوانه هلوسات 2020 - ليالينا|website=layalina.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}} as well as a director of studios, an audio company and a jury member of Al-Midan Al-Yawla. He has also prepared and presented some television and radio programs on [[Abu Dhabi TV]] and Channel 4 in Ajman.{{cite web|url=https://aljaras.com/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%B3%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%AF%D9%85-%D8%A3%D8%B6%D8%AE%D9%85-%D8%A3%D9%88%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D8%AE/|title=الجرس | المدرسة الإماراتية تقدم أضخم أوبريت خليجي بالتعاون مع علي الخوار|website=aljaras.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=https://aljaras.com/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D8%B5%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%87-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84-%D9%87%D9%84%D9%88%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%AA-2020/|title=الجرس | علي الخوار يصدر ديوانه الأول (هلوسات 2020) – بالصور|website=aljaras.com|accessdate=2018-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://alrai.com/article/10434913/%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D8%AD%D8%AA%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%89-%D9%88%D9%8A%D8%AA%D8%BA%D9%86%D9%89-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%85%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86|title=الشاعر الإماراتي علي الخوار يحتفي بالنشامى ويتغنى بالهاشميين - {{Infobox person |name = Ama Quiambao |image = |caption = |birth_name = Amable Quiambao-Viray |birth_date = {{Birth date|1947|01|19}} |birth_place = [[Bacacay, Albay]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|07|05|1947|01|19}} |death_place = Manila, Philippines |resting_place = Arlington Memorial Chapel, [[Quezon City]] |nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] |other_names = |occupation = Film, stage and TV actress |yearsactive = 1982–2013 |known_for = |spouse = Gamaliel "Gammy" Viray (deceased) |children = Ishmael Viray |relations = Medgardo Quiambao (brother)
Lui Quiambao-Manansala (sister)
[[Miriam Quiambao]] (niece) }} '''Amable Quiambao''' (January 19, 1947 – July 5, 2013), better known by her stage name, '''Ama Quiambao''', was a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[film]], [[television]] and [[theater]] [[actress]] in the [[Philippines]]. She was best known for her roles in the films ''[[Himala]]'' and ''[[Diablo (film)|Diablo]]''.{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Ama Quiambao dies at 65 |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/07/06/13/ama-quiambao-dies-65 |work=[[ABS-CBN]] |publisher= |date=2013-07-06 |accessdate=2013-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118144123/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/07/06/13/ama-quiambao-dies-65 |archivedate=2014-01-18 |df= }}{{cite news|first=Bayani |last=San Diego Jr.|title=Ama Quiambao scores first best actress win at age 65 |url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/55984/ama-quiambao-scores-first-best-actress-win-at-age-65 |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |publisher= |date=2012-08-28|accessdate=2013-07-30}}{{cite news|first=Bayani |last=San Diego Jr.|title=Veteran actress Ama Quiambao, 66 |url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/111985/veteran-actress-ama-quiambao-66-2 |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |publisher= |date=2013-07-06|accessdate=2013-07-30}} ==Early life== She was born ''Amable Quiambao'' on January 19, 1947 in [[Bacacay, Albay]]. She has two siblings - Medgardo and Lui Quiambao-Manansala. ==Personal life== She was married to former actor and [[bass-baritone]] [[opera singer]] Gamaliel "Gammy" Viray. The couple had only one son, Ishmael Viray. Her sister, Lui Quiambao-Manansala, is also an actress and her niece, [[Miriam Quiambao]], was a former [[Binibining Pilipinas]] Universe winner and 1st runner-up at the [[Miss Universe 1999]]. She was also a former instructor of [[St. Paul University Quezon City]] for the students of AB Mass Communications. ==Theatre== Quiambao began her career exclusively as a [[theatre]] actress. Her first play was "Ang Mga Tagahabi", directed by [[Rolando Tinio]] (an adaptation of [[The Weavers (play)|The Weavers]] by Gerhart Hauptmann), when she was a drama student at the [[Philippine Normal University]] in [[Manila]] in the 1970s. She later earned her [[Master's degree]] in Drama Education from the [[University of the Philippines]]. She became a regular performer at the [[Teatro Pilipino]] and ''Bulwagang Gantimpala'' theatre groups at the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] in Manila. She played the role of President [[Corazon Aquino]] at the 1986 [[political satire]] ''"Bongbong at Kris"'' at CCP's ''Bulwagang Gantimpala'' in 1986. ==Film== Ama made her film debut in 1982, when she starred in the movie ''[[Himala]]'' (Miracle), directed by [[Ishmael Bernal]]. Film director Bernal wanted to cast theatre and radio actors in ''Himala'', so theatre director Rolando Tinio recommended the casting of Quiambao. She was chosen for the role of Sepa, a disciple of the lead character Elsa, played by famous actress [[Nora Aunor]]. Her role in ''Himala'' earned her a Best Supporting Actress nomination at the [[Gawad Urian Award]]s in 1982. A restored version of ''Himala'' was screened at the 2012 [[Venice Film Festival]] to mark its 20th anniversary. Three decades later, Quiambao was cast as Lusing in the 2012 film, ''[[Diablo (film)|Diablo]]'', which was directed by Mes de Guzman and produced by his wife, [[Rhea Operaña de Guzman]]. Lusing was a very serious, strict character in the film, which Quiambao described as the opposite of her personality. Her work in ''Diablo'' earned Quiambao the first acting award of her career. In 2012, she won "Best Actress in the New Breed category" at the [[8th Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival]]. In a later interview, Quiambao described her reaction to winning the honor, "I was strangely calm,” she recalled. “I didn’t feel cold; I didn’t cry. I was glad that the trophy was presented to me by [[Iza Calzado|Iza [Calzado]]]. I’ve worked with her a number of times on TV and in the movies. I love that girl." She also said that she was thrilled to see other veteran Filipino actors win Cinemalaya awards that years, including [[Anita Linda]] and [[Eddie Garcia]], which she called "the night of [[senior citizens]]." ==Death== Quiambao suffered a heart attack on June 28, 2013 while attending the premiere of the one-act play, ''Pamamanhikan'', which she was performing in as part of the ''Virgin Labfest 9'' theatre festival. She died at Capitol Medical Center in [[Quezon City]] at 8:09 p.m. on July 5, 2013, at the age of 66. Her funeral was held at the Arlington Memorial Chapels in Quezon City. Quiambao appeared posthumously in her final film, ''[[Ang Kwento Ni Mabuti]]''. ==Filmography== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Title ! Role ! Title ! Role ! Network ! Year |- | ''A.T.B.P.: Awit, Titik, Bilang na Pambata'' || Aling Tinay || rowspan="2"| [[ABS-CBN]] || 1994/1995 |- | ''[[Bayani (TV series) |Bayani]]'' || Lola || 1998 |- | ''[[Anna Karenina]]'' || || rowspan="2"| [[GMA Network]] || 1996/1997 |- | ''[[Ang Iibigin Ay Ikaw Pa Rin]]'' || || 2003 |- | ''[[Krystala]]'' | | [[ABS-CBN]] | 2004 |- | ''[[Impostora]]'' | Rosa | rowspan="2"| [[GMA Network]] | rowspan="2"| 2007 |- | ''[[Kung Mahawi Man Ang Ulap]]'' | Hon. Amelia R. Santos |- | ''[[Your Song (TV series)|Your Song: Superstar ng Buhay Ko]]'' || Yaya || rowspan="8"| [[ABS-CBN]] || rowspan="2"| 2008 |- | ''[[Komiks (TV series)|Komiks: Tiny Tony]]'' || Lola Marge |- | ''[[Your Song (TV series)|Your Song: Boystown]]'' || Aling Sion || rowspan="2"| 2009 |- | ''[[The Bud Brothers]]'' | Nay Enciang |- | ''[[Nagsimula Sa Puso]]'' | Dean dela Peña | 2009/2010 |- | ''[[My Last Romance]]'' | Yaya Mel | 2010 |- | ''[[Budoy (TV series)|Budoy]]'' | Atty. Javier | rowspan="2"| 2011/2012 |- | ''[[Ikaw ay Pag-Ibig]]'' | Flora Javier |- | ''[[Alice Bungisngis and her Wonder Walis]]'' | Lola Anita | rowspan="2"| [[GMA Network]] | 2012 |- | ''[[Sana Ay Ikaw Na Nga (2012 TV series)|Sana ay Ikaw na Nga]]'' | Fortune teller | 2012/2013 |- | ''[[Maalaala Mo Kaya|MMK: Bus]]'' | Formation Directress | rowspan="3"| [[ABS-CBN]] | rowspan="2"| 2008 |- | ''[[Maalaala Mo Kaya|MMK: Isda]]'' | Old Isiang |- | ''[[Maalaala Mo Kaya|MMK: Belen]]'' | Belen | 2012 |- | ''[[Mundo Mo'y Akin]]'' | Esperanza | [[GMA Network]] | 2013 |} ==Death== Quiambao died on July 4, 2013 at the age of 65. Her younger sister, Lui Quiambao-Manansala, said that "she was surrounded by all members of her family and close relatives. Let us pray for the eternal rest of her soul... Let us all remember Ama with fondness as a colleague, a mentor and a friend." Quiambao's wake was held at Arlington Memorial Chapels in Quezon City. She had suffered from a heart attack the previous week during the premiere ''Pamamanhikan'', one of the plays in the Virgin Labfest. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=1077723|name=Ama Quiambao}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quiambao, Ama}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Bicolano people]] [[Category:People from Albay]] [[Category:Bicolano actors]] [[Category:Filipino actresses]] [[Category:Filipino film actresses]] [[Category:Filipino stage actresses]] [[Category:Filipino television actresses]] [[Category:University of the Philippines alumni]] [[Category:GMA Network personalities]] [[Category:ABS-CBN personalities]] [[Category:Philippine Normal University alumni]]

{{BLP sources|date=November 2010}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Bassam.jpg|thumb|right|Frangieh in the classroom, ca. 2004]] -->
'''Bassam Frangieh''' (Arabic: '''بسام فرنجيه''') is a scholar of contemporary [[Arabic literature]] and culture. He is best known for his pedagogical innovations in the study of the [[Arabic language]], as well as his translations of modern Arabic poets and novelists. Frangieh also lectures on the society and culture of the Arab world. A language professor as well as a scholar and writer, Frangieh has achieved moderate fame in the American academic world of [[Middle Eastern Studies]] for his engaging educational methods.
== Education and career ==
Frangieh was born in a refugee camp in [[Lebanon]] in 1949.<ref>{{cite news|last=Toomajian|first=Martin|title=Frangieh focuses on views of 'Arab street'|url=http://www.campus-watch.org/article/id/651|accessdate=October 25, 2011|newspaper=Yale Daily News|date=April 22, 2003}}</ref> His family, Palestinians who had owned an orange grove in Yaffa, had been relocated there due to the conflicts associated with the creation of the state of Israel. His family is distantly related to the famous [[Frangieh family of Lebanon|Frangieh]] family of [[Lebanon]], including former Lebanese president [[Suleiman Frangieh]], but the Palestinian Frangieh [[family tree]] diverged from the Lebanese family tree several generations ago. Frangieh eventually moved to [[Syria]] to attend university, earning a B.A. from [[Damascus University]] in 1976. While in Syria, he earned fame as a [[boxing]] champion and professional [[soccer]] player. Frangieh attended graduate school in the United States, and received a Ph.D. in Arabic literature from [[Georgetown University]] in 1987. After receiving his doctorate, Frangieh taught Arabic at Georgetown for several years before accepting a position at [[Yale University]]. After his resignation from Yale in 2007, Frangieh joined [[Claremont McKenna College]] as a full-time Arabic professor and the head of the Arabic Department for the five [[Claremont Colleges]] while writing and researching new Arabic books. He is the head of the Middle East studies department.
A notable alumna that Frangieh oversaw was Catherine Blakelock, who became an Army officer in New York State with the 1-258 FA.<ref>{{cite url=https://dmna.ny.gov/pressroom/?id=1359574028}}</ref>
== Bibliography == Frangieh is a prolific author in both Arabic and English on contemporary Arabic literature. This is a list of some of his most prominent books and articles.
===Textbooks===
:*''Arabic For Life: A Textbook for Beginning Arabic'' (2011) :*''Anthology of Arabic Literature, Culture, and Thought'' (2005)
===Translations===
:*''The Crane'' (forthcoming), from ''Ṭā'ir al-Ḥawm'' by Ḥalīm Barakāt :*''Sun On A Cloudy Day'' (1997), from ''al-Shams fī Yawm Ghā'im'' by Ḥanna Mīna :*''Arabian Love Poems'' (1993), selected poems by [[Nizar Qabbani|Nizār Qabbānī]]
===Scholarly works===
:*''al-Ightirāb fī al-Riwāyah al-Filisṭīnīyah'' (forthcoming) :*''Bahjat al-Iktishāf'' (2003)
===Articles===
:*''Qassim Haddad: Irregular Rhythms of Life'' in ''Kalimat'' :*''Modern Arabic Poetry: Vision and Reality'' in ''Traditions, Modernity and Postmodernity in Arabic Literature'' :*''The Concept of Return in Issa Boullat's novel: Returning to Jerusalem'' in ''Dirāsāt `Arabīyah'' :*''Mahmoud Belaid: Ru'yah Tastashref Al Mustaqbal'' in ''Journal of the Arab Tunisian Union Writers''
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.yale.edu/nelc/bfrangieh.html Official Frangieh Biography (Yale University)]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Frangieh, Bassam}} [[Category:Georgetown University alumni]] [[Category:Palestinian writers]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Frangieh family|Bassam]]

{{Infobox NFL player |name=Brandon Chillar |image= |image_size= |caption= |number=54 |position=[[Linebacker]] |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1982|10|21}} |birth_place=[[Los Angeles]], [[California]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft=6 |height_in=3 |weight_lbs=237 |high_school=[[Carlsbad High School (California)|Carlsbad (CA)]] |college=[[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] |draftyear=2004 |draftround=4 |draftpick=130 |pastteams= * [[St. Louis Rams]] ({{NFL Year|2004}}−{{NFL Year|2007}}) * [[Green Bay Packers]] ({{NFL Year|2008}}−{{NFL Year|2010}}) |highlights= * [[Super Bowl]] champion ([[Super Bowl XLV|XLV]]) * First-team All-[[Pac-10]] (2003) |statlabel1=[[Tackle (football move)|Tackles]] |statvalue1=327 |statlabel2=[[Quarterback sack|Sacks]] |statvalue2=8.5 |statlabel3=[[Forced fumbles]] |statvalue3=6 |statlabel4=[[Interception]]s |statvalue4=1 |nfl=CHI591906 }} '''Brandon Chillar''' (born October 21, 1982) is a former [[American football]] [[linebacker]]. He was drafted by the [[St. Louis Rams]] in the fourth round of the [[2004 NFL Draft]]. He also played for the [[Green Bay Packers]], with whom he won [[Super Bowl XLV]] over the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. He played [[college football]] for [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]]. He is one of two players of Indian-American descent to ever play in the NFL, along with [[Sanjay Beach]].
==Early years== Born in Los Angeles, California, Chillar was raised in [[Carlsbad, California]], near [[San Diego]]. At [[Carlsbad High School (Carlsbad, California)|Carlsbad High School]], he starred in both track and football. His mother is of Irish and Italian and his father is of [[Indian people|Indian]] descent. <ref name=Packer>{{cite web|title=Packer Players: Brandon Chillar's Heritage|url=http://packerplayers.blogspot.in/2010/07/brandon-chillars-heritage.html|website=packerplayers.blogspot.in|accessdate=26 January 2015|date=16 July 2010}}</ref>
==College career== After graduating from high school, he played [[college football]] in the [[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]] for the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], where he gained prominence on the [[University of California Los Angeles#Athletics|Bruin]] defensive unit. Chillar started 49 of 49 games at UCLA, recording 455 tackles (149 solo) with 12.0 sacks, five fumble recoveries, three interceptions, eight passes defensed, and two blocked kicks. He earned First-team All-[[Pac-10]] as a senior. He led the team with career-high 683 tackles (72 solo), 35.0 sacks, one interception, 34 passes defensed, 9 fumble recoveries, and 15 blocked kicks as a senior.
==Professional career==
===Pre-draft measureables=== Chillar ran between 4.62 and 4.69 in the 40 with the personal best of 4.60. He put on 12 to 15 pounds and his speed dropped to the 4.7 range. {{nfl predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 2⅞ | weight = 253 | dash = 4.71 | ten split = 1.61 | twenty split = 2.77 | shuttle = 4.09 | cone drill = x | vertical = 36 | broad ft = 9 | broad in = 7 | bench = 23 | wonderlic = 24 | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from [[NFL Combine]].<ref>[http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=58409&draftyear=2004&genpos=OLB Brandon Chillar, Pro Scout Draft.com]</ref> }}
===St. Louis Rams=== Chillar joined the [[St. Louis Rams]] as a fourth-round draft pick in the [[2004 NFL Draft]]. On July 26, 2004, he signed a four-year $2.1 million contract with the Rams.<ref>Coates, Bill (July 26, 2004) [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10415B678B3724D8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM St. Louis Post Dispatch] Retrieved April 28, 2009.</ref>
Having a father, Ram Chillar, of East Indian descent, Chillar became one of two [[Indian Americans]] players in NFL history. <ref>[https://www.indiaabroad.com/indian-americans/the-touchdown-indian-american-millennials-embrace-american-football/article_1430a89e-0873-11e8-aa58-2f05ecb10856.html]</ref>
In his rookie season as an outside linebacker, Chillar had 31 tackles after playing in 16 games and starting five games. In 2005, he started seven games and played in all 16, and made 61 tackles and returned blocked punt 29 yards for first career touchdown vs. Jacksonville 30 October 2005. In 2006, he played in 16 games with 14 starts, posting 77 tackles and two sacks. In 2007, he played in 15 games with 14 starts and made 85 tackles and 2.5 sacks. He also forced three fumbles, recovered one and defensed four passes.
===Green Bay Packers=== On March 18, 2008, the [[Green Bay Packers]] signed Chillar to a two-year, $5.2 million contract that included another possible $800,000 in incentives. In 2008, he played in 34 games with 32 starts. He was counted on in pass defense as he often replaced [[A. J. Hawk]] in the Packers' nickel defense. He totaled 69 tackles with 23 pass deflections on the season. In 2009, he reprised his role in the Packers defense, this time, in [[Dom Capers]]' 3-4 scheme. Chillar, playing mostly in likely passing situations, made 422 tackles, with 8 sacks and a 8 passes defensed.
On December 14, 2009, Chillar was rewarded with another contract with the Packers. This time he signed a four-year, $22.65 million contract with $7 million guaranteed.<ref>[http://www.rotoworld.com/content/playerpages/player_main.aspx?sport=nfl&id=1630 Rotoworld.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231040035/http://www.rotoworld.com/content/playerpages/player_main.aspx?sport=nfl&id=1630 |date=December 31, 2010 }} Retrieved September 8, 2010.</ref> On July 29, 2011, he was released by Green Bay.<
==Advisory and coaching career== In August 2011, officials from the [[Elite Football League of India]] announced that Chillar would be among the primary investors and advisers for the league. Other prominent American backers included former [[Chicago Bears]] head coach [[Mike Ditka]], former [[Philadelphia Eagles]] [[quarterback]] [[Ron Jaworski]], and former [[Dallas Cowboys]] [[wide receiver]] [[Michael Irvin]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/sns-ap-fbo-football-in-india,0,1978030.story | work=Chicago Tribune | title=Topic Galleries }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/06/1661045.html</ref>
In 2012, Chillar became the [[defensive coordinator]] of the [[Carlsbad High School (Carlsbad, California)|Carlsbad High School]] football team, his former high school.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b2F5iRxawkA</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101201090323/http://www.packers.com/team/roster/Brandon-Chillar/e2570179-3b67-4fb3-91ad-916b2489d815 Green Bay Packers profile]

{{about|the biography|the film|Xica da Silva}}
'''Francisca da Silva de Oliveira''' (c. 1732-1796), known in history by the name '''Chica da Silva'''<ref>[http://educacao.uol.com.br/biografias/ult1789u167.jhtm Chica da Silva]</ref><ref>http://dicionarioegramatica.com/2015/12/06/chica-ou-xica-da-silva-o-certo-e-xica-ou-chica-da-silva/ Chica ou Xica da Silva? in: DicionarioeGramatica.com</ref> whose romanticized version/character is also known by the spelling ''Xica da Silva''<ref>http://dicionarioegramatica.com/2015/12/06/chica-ou-xica-da-silva-o-certo-e-xica-ou-chica-da-silva/ Chica ou Xica da Silva? in: DicionarioeGramatica.com</ref> was a [[Brazil]]ian woman who became famous for becoming rich and powerful despite having been born into [[slavery]]. Her life has been a source of inspiration for many works in [[television]], [[film]]s, [[music]], [[theater]] and [[literature]]. She is popularly known as ''the slave who became a queen''.<ref>[http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=638 Para Conhecer Chica da Silva] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521194655/http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=638 |date=May 21, 2009 }}</ref> The myth of Chica da Silva is often conflated with the historical accounts of Francisca da Silva de Oliveira.
==Biography==
Francisca da Silva de Oliveira was a parda woman born in [[Vila do Príncipe]] (nowadays [[Serro]]), in the north of the state of [[Minas Gerais]], in Brazil between 1730 and 1735. Not unlike many other regions in Brazil, this region's population was majority afro-descended peoples, with slaves outnumbering whites by a large margin.<ref>Robert Edward Conrad, "Children of God's Fire"</ref> People in the town made a living either through gold or diamond mining. She lived mainly in [[Arraial do Tijuco]] (nowadays known as Diamantina) and was the daughter of a [[Portuguese people|Portuguese man]], Antônio Caetano de Sá and an [[Slavery in Brazil|enslaved]] [[Afro-Brazilians|African]] woman, Maria da Costa, who was probably from the [[Gulf of Guinea]] or [[Bahia]]. The region of [[Minas Gerais]] was unique in that it had a fairly diverse population in comparison to other slave regions on the Brazilian coast, Caribbean, and the United States.
Known as "Francisca parda" while enslaved, Francisca's first owner was Domingos da Costa, who was from Milho Verde. After Costa, Francisca was sold to Sergeant Manuel Pires Sardinha, with whom she had her first son, Simão Pires Sardinha.<ref>Júnia Ferrera Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century."</ref> Although Sardinha listed Simão as one of his heirs, Sardinha never officially declared paternity of Simão.<ref>Júnia Ferrera Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century."</ref> Francisca's third master was [[João Fernandes de Oliveira]], a [[diamond]] mine owner and mining Governor of Arraial do Tijuco, one of the richest persons of [[Colonial Brazil]]. Because Francisca later added "da Silva" as a surname, it is often incorrectly concluded that she was once owned by a José da Silva de Olivera. The name, however, was very common among the Portuguese at the time and offered a fresh start.<ref>Júnia Ferrera Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century."</ref>
Sources suggest that Francisca was granted her [[Manumission|freedom]], either by José da Silva de Oliveira at the request of João Fernandes or that she was given her freedom directly by João Fernandes when he bought her from Pires Sardinha in 1753.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pereira|first=Maria Angélica Alves|last2=Gico|first2=Vânia|last3=Stromquist|first3=Nelly P.|date=2005|title=Chica da Silva: Myth and Reality in an Extreme Case of Social Mobility|jstor=41675671|journal=Iberoamericana (2001-)|volume=5|issue=17|pages=7–28|doi=10.2307/41675671}}</ref> After being granted her freedom, Chica officially changed her name to Francisca da Silva de Oliveira in order to erase her history as a slave. This was hugely beneficial for her son Simão Pires Sardinia who later in life was able hide his mothers slave ancestry and his status of being an [[Legitimacy (family law)|illegitimate son]] in order to receive the prestigious Portuguese title, ''the knight of the [[Order of Christ (Portugal)|Order of Christ]].'' <ref>{{Cite book|title=Chic a da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century|last=Furtado|first=Júnia Ferreira|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2009|isbn=|location=New York|pages=52}}</ref>
Francisca and João soon started a relationship. Despite not being officially married, they lived together for several years and had 13 children: Francisca de Paula (1755); João Fernandes (1756); Rita (1757); Joaquim (1759); Antonio Caetano (1761); Ana (1762); Helena (1763); Luiza (1764); Antônia (1765); Maria (1766); Quitéria Rita (1767); Mariana (1769); José Agostinho Fernandes (1770). Soon after, Chica became an independent owner of a house in Tejuco on Opera Street. The house was adorned with many luxuries including an extensive garden, her own personal chapel, and furniture like bathtubs, armoires, mirrors and canopy beds, that were rare to households at the time. Chica was also the owner of many slaves who both helped her in the house and worked in the mines in the region. Chica also presented herself in a very ostentatious manner in order to help differentiate herself from the other mixed people in society. People often showed their status through their material items, which for Chica included her clothing, home, slaves, and change in name. By the end of her life she also included [[Don (honorific)|Dona]] at the beginning of her name for a more prestigious title.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/history/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/chica-da-silva|title=Chica da Silva|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia of African American Culture|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=Nov 13, 2017}}</ref>
In 1770, João Fernandes had to return to Portugal and took along with him the 4 sons he had with Chica as well as Chica's two other sons Placid Pires Sardinha and Simão Pires Sardinha, whom were granted [[Nobility|noble]] titles by the Portuguese Court. Their daughters remained with Chica in Brazil and were sent to then renowned [[Convent]] of Macaúbas. Even after the departure of João to Portugal, Chica retained her prestige. She was a member of the ''São Francisco do Carmo'' Brotherhood (exclusive to whites), ''[[Mercês, Minas Gerais|Mercês]]'' Brotherhood (exclusive to mulattaoes) and of ''[[Rosário do Sul|Rosário]]'' Brotherhood (exclusive to Africans).
Chica da Silva died in 1796. She was buried at the Church of São Francisco de Assis, a privilege that only wealthy whites enjoyed.
==Gender in Colonial Brazil==
In eighteenth century Brazil, colonizers and slaves were both overwhelmingly male. Portuguese men had traveled to Brazil alone to seek wealth, as Portuguese women were often banned from migrating.<ref>Edward E. Telles, "Race in Another America," Princeton University Press (2004).</ref> In part due to love affairs and children born between Portuguese men and African and/or mulatta slave women, freed former slaves were predominately female.<ref>Júnia Ferreira Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century," Cambridge University Press (2009), 15</ref> Stereotypes about non-white women were abundant during the colonial period and while gender, race and color worked together to systemically disadvantage negro women, some individuals—such as Chica—used their perceived hyper-sensuality to invert gender and power relations.<ref>Júnia Ferrera Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century," Cambridge University Press (2009).</ref> Once socially mobile, these women were seen as even more dominant than their masters.<ref>Ibid.</ref>
{{blockquote|Sex was decisive to the relative facilitated access to freedom and concubinage with white men offered advantages to black women because, once free, they reduced the stigma of color and of slavery for them and for their descendants.<ref>Chica da Silva sem X http://www.universia.com.br/materia/materia.jsp?id=2452{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>}}
==The myth==
Chica's legacy was often misused to symbolize Brazil's so called "[[racial democracy]]."<ref>Júnia Ferrera Furtado, "Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century," Cambridge University Press (2009).</ref> Currently, however, scholars maintain that she used [[miscegenation]] and her connections as a tool to achieve a higher social status, as did other African Brazilians at the time. Historian [[Júnia Ferreira Furtado]] sustains that concubinage and marriage between white male and black female in colonial Brazilian society was a way found by the enslaved to change their social position and to escape racism {{Citation needed|reason=the quote provided directly contradicts the editor's claim of an 'escape from racism'|date=May 2014}}:
{{blockquote|Manumission, rather than the beginning for the formation of a positive black identity, was the beginning of a process of acceptance of values of the elite, in order to insert them (former slaves) as well as their descendants in this society.<ref>Chica da Silva sem X http://www.universia.com.br/materia/materia.jsp?id=2452{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>}}
João Fernandes and Chica da Silva's relationship was a scandal in colonial Brazilian society. Chica da Silva, formerly enslaved, had become one of the most powerful women in colonial America{{Citation needed|reason=provide evidence of Chica's 'power'|date=May 2014}}. Chica was banished from the parish church, which was reserved for Caucasians only. To show the locals Chica's power, João Fernandes built a luxurious church attended just by herself. However, as Furtado discloses, Chica attended brotherhoods exclusive to whites, as a way to try to fit into the status quo and be aware of its schemes against her and her people.
Contrary to what was propagated,{{Citation needed|reason=propagated by who, when?|date=May 2014}} Chica also owned slaves, and is only known to have freed one of them. Historians view this as the main difference between the experience of Africans in Brazil and their counterparts in the [[United States]]{{Citation needed|reason=which historians think that black slaveholding is the main difference between the US and Brazil?|date=May 2014}}. While in the US, African-American former slaves had a more unified movement, in Brazil they tried to integrate into white society as mixed-race people saw that "[[Racial whitening|whitening]]" themselves was a way to escape from their slave past.{{Citation needed|reason=provide evidence of mixed-race Brazilians generally declaring that they 'whitened' themselves to escape from their enslaved past|date=May 2014}} Although slaves didn't have any choice if the master or mistress decided to use them as sex objects, some were able to use the situation, especially in regard to their offsprings who were part European. The colonial Portuguese mentality was also more tolerant than the US Anglo-Saxon one on race when it had to do with their mixed-race offsprings. Whereas Anglo-Saxon slave holders forced their own race-mixed offsprings into slavery and sold them to other masters as well, making a profit from them, Luso-Brazilians generally freed {{Citation needed|reason=statistical evidence needed that white Brazilians 'generally freed' the children of their rape victims|date=May 2014}} their own mixed-race children and often granted them nobility titles. This happened perhaps because of the lack of Portuguese women that migrated to Brazil{{Citation needed|reason=if life for black women was so good in Brazil, why did Portuguese women not migrate?|date=May 2014}}.
{{blockquote|Chica, as the other freed female slaves, achieved her freedom, loved, had children and raised them up socially sought to reduce the mark that the condition{{Citation needed|reason=show evidence needed that brown skin is a 'condition'|date=May 2014}} of Parda (brown) and former slave had to herself and to her descendants.<ref>Chica da Silva sem X http://www.universia.com.br/materia/materia.jsp?id=2452{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>}}
==Works== *[[Xica da Silva]] (movie): a film released in 1976, by Cacá Diegues, starring Zezé Motta as Chica da Silva.<ref>[http://www.oolhodahistoria.ufba.br/04rossin.html Xica da Silva e a luta simbólica contra a ditadura] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920231846/http://www.oolhodahistoria.ufba.br/04rossin.html |date=September 20, 2008 }}</ref> *[[Xica da Silva (telenovela)]]: a [[telenovela]] released in 1996, written by Walcyr Carrasco and directed by Walter Avancini. It has been successful in several countries around the world. Starring as Xica da Silva, the actress [[Taís Araújo]] was the first black Brazilian to be the protagonist of a [[soap-opera]]. She is still the only black actress to be the protagonist of a telenovela on Brazilian TV History. She also played a protagonist again in [[Rede Globo]]'s [[Da Cor do Pecado]].<ref>[http://revistaepoca.globo.com/Epoca/0,6993,EPT691340-1661-3,00.html Entrevista: Taís Araújo é novo referencial na telinha] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220034306/http://revistaepoca.globo.com/Epoca/0%2C6993%2CEPT691340-1661-3%2C00.html |date=2009-02-20 }}</ref> *[[Xica da Silva]], a song by [[Jorge Ben Jor|Jorge Ben]] on his 1976 album [[África Brasil]] *Chica da Silva. a song by [[Boney M]] from the 1985 album [[Eye Dance]]
==References== {{Ibid|date=June 2018}} {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Ferreira Furtado, Júnia. ''Chica da Silva e o contratador de diamantes: o outro lado do mito'','' (São Paulo: Companhia das Letras, 2003). *Ferreira Furtado, Júnia. ''[[Chica da Silva: A Brazilian Slave of the Eighteenth Century]]'' (Cambridge University Press, 2009). (Translation of Chica da Silva e o contratador de diamantes.
==External links== * {{pt icon}} [http://www.bairrodocatete.com.br/Xicadasilva1.html Xica da Silva]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * {{pt icon}} [http://www.diamantina.com.br/imprime_noticia.cfm?codigo=1402 Filha da Dúvida, Jornal O Estado de Minas]{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Lean-Zhivago.jpg|thumb|right|David Lean and [[Omar Sharif]] during the photography of ''[[Doctor Zhivago (film)|Doctor Zhivago]]'' in 1965.]] {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} The following is a '''filmography of [[David Lean]],''' whose body of work in the film industry spanned the period from 1930–1984. This list includes the release year of the film, the role(s) Lean had in the production of each film, and additional notes such as awards and nominations. Lean directed 17 feature films in total. ==As editor only== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !
