revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Nina Dudnik | post-nominals = PhD | image = Nina_Dudnik_at_Pop_Tech_2010.jpg | residence = Boston, MA | education = [[Harvard University]] [[Brown University]] | occupation = CEO, Seeding Labs | known_for = Global development, science diplomacy, social entrepreneurship | awards = John F. Kennedy New Frontier Award, TEDGlobal Fellow, Boston Business Journal Innovation All Star }}
'''Nina Dudnik''' is a social entrepreneur, science diplomacy advocate, and the founder and CEO of Seeding Labs, a US-based nonprofit organization investing in building scientific capacity in the developing world. Dudnik founded the organization in 2003 as a graduate student studying at [[Harvard University]], where she received her PhD in molecular biology.
== Education and early career == Dudnik received her Bachelors of Science in [[biochemistry]] from [[Brown University]]. Between college and graduate school, she worked in agricultural development as a consultant for [[CGIAR]] (Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research) in Italy, and then became a [[Fulbright scholar]] in [[Cote d’Ivoire]].<ref name=":3" /> After her year in Africa, she returned to the United States to attend [[Harvard University]], where she received her PhD in [[molecular biology]]. She did her doctoral work in the laboratory of Dr. Kami Ahmad, where she ultimately published her dissertation, "Histone dimers on the move: Nucleosome assembly systems for H2A and H2AV in ''Drosophila''."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://search.proquest.com/openview/ef4de56b71402ffc2f0e3cf4f5b3587e/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750&diss=y|title=Histone dimers on the move: Nucleosome assembly systems for H2A and H2AV in Drosophila|last=Dudnik|first=Nina|publisher=ProQuest Dissertations Publishing|year=2008|isbn=|location=|publication-place=Cambridge, MA|pages=}}</ref>
== Global development work == Dudnik had personally felt the effects of lack of access to scientific resources in developing countries when doing her Fulbright work in Côte d'Ivoire, where she was working to breed better varieties of rice. There, she saw a gap between a wealth of scientific talent and a dearth of access to research equipment to put that talent to use.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/10/26/141666558/used-lab-equipment-finds-a-second-home-overseas|title=Used Lab Equipment Finds A Second Home Overseas|last=Daniel|first=Ari|date=October 26, 2011|work=NPR|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.nature.com/naturejobs/2015/06/15/transferable-skills-beyond-the-bench/|title=Transferable skills: Beyond the bench : Naturejobs Blog|website=blogs.nature.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> When she returned to the United States to pursue her doctoral degree, she worked to bridge that gap. She led a group of fellow students in collecting surplus biological equipment and supplies at Harvard University to send to labs in developing countries to support the research they were doing at their local institutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gould|first=Julie|date=2015-11-11|title=Non-profit organizations: Scientists on a mission|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v527/n7577/full/nj7577-265a.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=527|issue=7577|pages=265–266|doi=10.1038/nj7577-265a|issn=0028-0836}}</ref> This effort became the basis of Seeding Labs, which formally launched in 2007 when Dudnik was awarded the [[Echoing Green]] fellowship.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.echoinggreen.org/fellows/nina-dudnik|title=Nina Dudnik {{!}} Echoing Green|website=www.echoinggreen.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> A year later, Seeding Labs was established as a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/10-8267613|title=Seeding Labs A Nonprofit Corporation - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
Dudnik and her team have since expanded Seeding Labs beyond equipment transfer, developing exchange programs to train scientists from developing countries in America.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/08/03/nonprofit-hosts-visiting-scientists/ffhfGtWL9T00sx2HYWNuHI/story.html|title=Nonprofit hosts visiting scientists - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> She has promoted the organization's vision as a TEDGlobal Fellow, a PopTech Social Innovation Fellow, and at the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/people/nina-dudnik|title=Nina Dudnik|website=World Economic Forum|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> They have received funding and support from a combination of government organizations like the [[United States Agency for International Development]], academic institutions like [[Harvard University]], and private companies like [[Merck & Co.|Merck]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usaid.gov/news-information/frontlines/may-june-2017/equipping-next-generation-scientists-and-medical-workers-ghana|title=Equipping the Next Generation of Scientists and Medical Workers in Ghana {{!}} FrontLines May/June 2017 {{!}} U.S. Agency for International Development|website=www.usaid.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://seedinglabs.org/2017/03/positively-instrumental-event/|title=“Positively Instrumental” Event Honors Donors, Instrumental Access 2017 Awardees • Seeding Labs|date=2017-03-23|work=Seeding Labs|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Science advocacy efforts == Dudnik has written on the need to build scientific capacity in developing countries to take on the world's most pressing health challenges for outlets like ''[[Scientific American]],'' ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', and ''[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]'', drawing attention to the lack of funding and research support for countries in the global South.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/if-you-want-to-cure-all-diseases-include-all-of-the-world-s-scientists/|title=If You Want to Cure All Diseases, Include All of the World's Scientists|last=Dudnik|first=Nina|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1016915/no-africa-is-not-lacking-talented-scientists-were-just-not-investing-in-them/|title=No, Africa is not lacking talented scientists. We’re just not investing in them|work=Quartz|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4750864/science-funding-diplomacy/|title=Why Scientists Should All Be Diplomats|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> After the [[West African Ebola virus epidemic|2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa]], she published an op-ed for the ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' underscoring the need to support developing scientific talent within Africa, which could have enabled earlier public health mobilization on the ground and prevented a wider Ebola outbreak without reliance on Western aid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nina-dudnik-addressing-africas-scientific-deficit-1416181052|title=Addressing Africa’s Scientific Deficit|last=Dudnik|first=Nina|date=2014-11-16|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
A woman in science herself, Dudnik has also written on issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM fields.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/voices/conversations-about-diversity-arent-working/|title=Conversations about Diversity Aren't Working|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}</ref> She is currently an Advisory Board member for the grassroots nonprofit [[500 Women Scientists]], which is working to make science open, inclusive, and accessible by promoting women scientists in leadership.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://500womenscientists.org/who-we-are|title=Who We Are|website=500 Women Scientists|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
== Awards and honors ==
*[[Echoing Green]] Global Fellow, 2007<ref name=":0" /> *[[TED (conference)|TED]]Global Fellow, 2010<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/profiles/536876/fellow|title=Nina Dudnik {{!}} TED Fellow {{!}} TED|website=www.ted.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}</ref> * PopTech Social Innovation Fellow, 2010<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://past.poptech.org/popcasts/nina_dudnik_seeding_labs|title=Nina Dudnik: Seeding Labs|website=PopTech|access-date=2018-07-04}}</ref> *[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'s Inspirational Women, The Fixers, 2011<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/news/g2580/the-fixers-9-for-all-mankind-566253/|title=The Fixers|date=2011-06-22|work=ELLE|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref> * John F. Kennedy New Frontier Award, 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jfklibrary.org/Events-and-Awards/New-Frontier-Award/Recipients/Nina-Dudnik-2014.aspx|title=Nina Dudnik 2014 - John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum|website=www.jfklibrary.org|access-date=2018-07-04}}</ref> * [[Scientific American]]'s 100 Most Influential People in Biotechnology, 2015 *[[New England Biolabs]] Passion in Science Humanitarian Duty Award, 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/new-england-biolabs-announces-2016-passion-in-science-awards-recipients-300324122.html|title=New England Biolabs® Announces 2016 Passion in Science Awards® Recipients|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref> *''Boston Business Journal'' Innovation All Star, 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2016/11/21/meet-the-2017-bbj-innovation-all-stars-bbj-photo.html|title=Meet the 2017 BBJ Innovation All-Stars|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Bot: Removing [[c:File:Ishigaki oohama oyakeakahachi2.jpg]] ([[:File:Ishigaki oohama oyakeakahachi2.jpg|en]]). Deleted by [[:C:User:Daphne Lantier|Daphne Lantier]] (per [[Commons:Commons:Deletion requests/Statue of Oyake Akahachi]]).
revision.text:
'''{{nihongo|Oyake Akahachi|遠弥計赤蜂<ref>Shinzato, Keiji<!--新里恵二--> et al. ''Okinawa-ken no rekishi'' (History of Okinawa Prefecture). Tokyo: Yamakawa Publishing, 1996. p57.</ref>}}''' was a [[Ryukyuan people|Ryukyuan]] lord ([[aji (Ryukyu)|aji]]) of [[Ishigaki Island]] who led a rebellion against the [[Ryukyu Kingdom]] in 1500.
==Early life and rebellion==
It is said that Akahachi was born on [[Hateruma]] Island, and that he was large and physically strong even as a child. He moved to [[Ishigaki, Okinawa|Ishigaki Island]] as a young adult, and became the chief of Ōhama Village (today part of Ishigaki City) soon afterward.<ref name=jinmei>"Oyake Akahachi." ''Okinawa rekishi jinmei jiten'' (沖縄歴史人名事典, "Encyclopedia of People of Okinawan History"). Naha: Okinawa Bunka-sha, 1996. p18.</ref> His influence soon extended over all of Ishigaki Island, and beyond, to other islands in the [[Yaeyama Islands]] group. At some point late in the 15th century, the nearby [[Miyako Islands]] were divided between two influential families, the Nakasone and Kaneshigawa, who were fighting one another for dominance of the area. Seeking to take advantage of the chaos and disunity, Akahachi proposed an invasion of the Miyako Islands. However, [[Nakasone Toyomiya]] led a counterattack against Akahachi, overwhelming his forces and moving on to attack [[Yonaguni Island]] as well.<ref>Kerr, George. ''Okinawa: the History of an Island People''. (revised ed.) Tokyo: Tuttle Publishing, 2000. p121.</ref>
At this time, the [[Ryukyu Kingdom]], based at [[Shuri, Okinawa|Shuri]] on [[Okinawa Island]], did not yet have direct control over the Yaeyama or Miyako Islands, but merely expected [[tribute]] to be paid. Akahachi led the people of Ishigaki and the surrounding islands in revolt against the kingdom, refusing to pay taxes or tribute. After Nakasone conquered Yaeyama, a force of roughly 3,000 Ryukyuan troops was sent by King [[Shō Shin]] in 1500, and the rebellion was suppressed with the annexation of the [[Sakishima Islands]].<ref name=jinmei/>
==Legacy== [[Image:Hateruma akahachi.jpg|thumb|Akahachi Memorial on Hateruma]] While official records and histories produced by the Ryukyu Kingdom label Oyake Akahachi as a rebel and a traitor, locally on Ishigaki and the surrounding islands he is known as a hero who sought to secure their freedom and independence.<ref name=jinmei/> A [[stele]] in his honor can be found today in the Ōhama area of Ishigaki City.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oyake, Akahachi}} [[Category:Aji (Ryukyu)]] [[Category:Rebels]] [[Category:Ryukyuan people]] [[Category:15th-century Ryukyuan people]] [[Category:16th-century Ryukyuan people]]

[[File:Pierre-François Palloy.png|thumb|right|Pierre-François Palloy]] [[File:Carnavalet_-_Modèle_réduit_de_la_Bastille_01.jpg|thumb|right|One of Palloy's models made from a stone from the Bastille]] '''Pierre-François Palloy''' (23 January 1755 – 1835), self-styled as '''''Palloy Patriote''''' ('''Palloy the Patriot''') was an entrepreneurial building contractor remembered for the demolition of the [[Bastille]].
==Life== Palloy was born in 1755 in Paris. Both his parents came from bourgeois families active in the wine retailing industry. Palloy was educated at the ''College d'Harcourt'', where many of the students were from upper-class liberal backgrounds.<ref>[[Simon Schama]], page 409 "[[Citizens: A Chronicle of the French Revolution]]", {{ISBN|0-670-81012-6}}</ref> He left school at the age of fifteen to join the [[French Royal Army (1652–1830)|French Royal Army]] as a cadet and then as an officer. On leaving this career at the age of twenty, he married the daughter of a building contractor and joined the trade himself, eventually taking over his new family's business. By 1789 he had made the company one of the largest building firms in Paris, employing 400 workers.<ref name="HJL">Lüsebrink, Hans-Jürgen. Reichardt, Rolf. ''The Bastille: a history of a symbol of despotism and freedom''. Duke University Press Books, 27 June 1997. p. 114–134</ref>
===Demolition of the Bastille=== When [[Storming of the Bastille|the Bastille fell]] on 14 July 1789 there was some debate as to what should replace it, or indeed if it should remain as a monument to the past. However, Palloy knew exactly what he wanted to do and by that evening had begun the process of dismantling the structure; he secured the contract to demolish the building two days later.<ref name="HJL" /> Most of the building was removed over the subsequent months by approximately 1,000 workers.<ref name="DF">[http://www.discoverfrance.net/France/Paris/Monuments-Paris/Bastille5.shtml Place de la Bastille, Part 5], Discover France. Accessed 20 August 2011.</ref> The [[dimension stone]]s were reused for the construction of the [[Pont de la Concorde (Paris)|Pont de la Concorde]].<ref name="CAS">[http://cultureandstuff.com/2011/05/24/lost-paris-the-elephant-on-the-place-de-la-bastille/ Lost Paris: The Elephant on the Place de la Bastille]. 24 May 2011. Accessed 20 August 2011.</ref>
Although Palloy did not receive the official payment for several years, he knew how to profit from the possession of such an iconic structure in the meantime. Staff conducted tours, for a fee, to show the public around the basements and dungeons with skeletons as props. Palloy labelled himself a [[patriotism|patriot]] and emphasised the symbolism of the Bastille, writing speeches, painting pictures, and even arranging celebratory festivals and theatrical reconstructions of the day the Bastille fell.<ref name="HJL" /> He sold other parts as souvenirs<ref name="CAS" /> including replica Bastilles made from the stones of the building itself. He even sent examples of these miniatures to each of the [[Departments of France|83 departments]] asking only to be reimbursed for transport and postage.<ref name="HJL" />
===Later life=== In early 1794 Palloy was held in prison on charges of [[embezzlement]] and of being a [[Hébertists|Hébertist]] but was released after two months.<ref name="HJL" /> In 1814 he was awarded the [[Décoration du Lys]].
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Palloy, Pierre-Francois}} [[Category:1755 births]] [[Category:1835 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Paris]] [[Category:People of the French Revolution]]

'''Raffique Shah''' is a [[Trinidad and Tobago]] [[trade union]] leader and political commentator. He is also a former [[Member of Parliament]] and mutineer, having led a mutiny of [[Trinidad and Tobago Regiment]] in 1970. He was born the son of a sugar cane worker and housewife in March 1946. His early education was at Presentation College, Chaguanas, where he gained a Grade I Cambridge School Certificate. He later won a cadetship to the prestigious [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]] between 1964 and 1966.
As a [[Lieutenant]] in the Trinidad and Tobago Regiment, he led an army mutiny in 1970. In the midst of [[Black Power]] riots, the [[People's National Movement]] government led by [[Eric Williams]] proclaimed a [[State of Emergency]] April, 1970 and arrested several Black Power leaders and [[Trade Union]]ists. In a move to prevent Williams from using the military against the masses, a portion of the Regiment stationed at Teteron (on the [[Chaguaramas, Trinidad|Chaguaramas]] Peninsula), led by [[Lieutenant]]s Shah and [[Rex Lassalle]] mutinied. In response, the [[Trinidad and Tobago Defence Force#Coast Guard|Trinidad and Tobago Coast Guard]] fired on the mutineers who returned to Teteron Barracks, abandoning their foray into Port of Spain. After ten days the mutineers surrendered. The leaders were [[court-martial]]ed and Shah and Lasalle were jailed. They both went on to win their appeals at the local Court of Appeal, and judges at the Privy Council in London, England, ruled against the State's appeal in July, 1972. Shah, Lassalle and all the other mutineers were freed within 24 hours of that ruling.
After being released from prison Shah joined the Trade Union movement leading the ICFTU, a body of cane farmers who sought to displace the government recognised organisation,TICFA. He, [[George Weekes]] and [[Basdeo Panday]] went on to found the [[United Labour Front]] in 1975 as a labor confederation and transformed it into a political party in 1976. During general election later that year, the ULF secured 10 of the 36 seats in [[House of Representatives of Trinidad and Tobago|Parliament]] and became the official [[Parliamentary Opposition|Opposition]]. [[Basdeo Panday]] was appointed [[Opposition (parliamentary)|Leader of the Opposition]], but following a bitter row in the party, Shah was able to displace him, and served as Leader of the Opposition between August 9, 1977 and March 31, 1978 when Panday regained control of the party.
Shah went on to lead the cane farmers and won an election to head the [[Trinidad Islandwide Cane Farmers' Association]] (TICFA), in 1998. He has been chairman of that organisation to date. Shah also served as editor of the ''Trinidad and Tobago Mirror'' newspaper for 17 years and today serves as an [[op-ed]] columnist in the ''Trinidad Express'' newspaper. He is also known as the man who founded the prestigious annual Clico Trinidad & Tobago International Marathon, an event that spawned road running throughout the Caribbean. He remained chairman of the organising committee until he stepped down in 2005. He served, too, as secretary of the local National Amateur Athletics Association and still holds a strong interest in sports in general and athletics in particular.

Varner]] | successor =[[Martin Massengale]] | title2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2= | successor2= | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|12|11}} | birth_place =[[Spencer, Iowa]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | alma_mater = [[University of Iowa]]
University of Northern Iowa | spouse= |religion= | party =Republican | occupation= }} '''Ronald William Roskens''' (born December 11, 1932) is an American academic. He was the president of the [[University of Nebraska System]] from 1977 to 1989.http://digital.omahapubliclibrary.org/earlyomaha/library/ronald_roskens.html Roskens is an alumnus of the [[University of Northern Iowa]].https://www.library.uni.edu/collections/special-collections/biographical-sketches/ronald-william-roskens[https://books.google.ca/books?id=hHqH51Vpe6UC&q=Ronald+Roskens+Nebraska+1932&dq=Ronald+Roskens+Nebraska+1932&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mNOEVZuFDomrNrSfgLgH&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAg] Roskens was a member and past National President of [[Sigma Tau Gamma]].{{cite web|title=Past National Presidents|url=http://sigtau.org/fraternity/leadership/past-national-presidents/|publisher=Sigma Tau Gamma|accessdate=16 July 2017}} He served as Administrator of USAID from 1990-1992 https://unomaha-public.lyrasistechnology.org/agents/people/61 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{University of Nebraska System presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roskens, Ronald}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:Presidents of the University of Nebraska System]] [[Category:University of Northern Iowa alumni]] [[Category:DeMolay International Hall of Fame members]]

{{Infobox royalty | name = Sineperver Sultan
سینه پرور سلطان | image = İstanbul 6000.jpg | caption = The tomb of Sinepervar Sultan
at the Fountain ''([[Şadırvan]])'' Courtyard of
[[Eyüp Sultan Mosque]] in [[Eyüp]], [[Istanbul]] | consort = yes | succession = [[Valide sultan]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] | reign = 29 May 1807 – 28 July 1808 | predecessor = [[Mihrişah Sultan]] | successor = [[Nakşidil Sultan]] | birth_name = Sonia/Sofia | birth_date = {{circa}} 1761 | birth_place = [[Rhodope Mountains]], [[Bulgaria]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1828|12|11|1761|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Istanbul]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | burial_place = [[Eyüp Sultan Mosque]], [[Eyüp]], Istanbul | spouse = [[Abdulhamid I]] | issue = [[Mustafa IV]]Yavuz Bahadıroğlu, Resimli Osmanlı Tarihi, Nesil Yayınları ''(Ottoman History with Illustrations, Nesil Publications)'', 15th Ed., 2009, page 395, {{ISBN|978-975-269-299-2}}
[[Esma Sultan (daughter of Abdul Hamid I)|Esma Sultan]]
Şehzade Ahmed
Fatma Sultan | full name = {{lang-tr|Sineperver Sultan}}
{{lang-eng|Sinaparwar Sultan}}
{{lang-ota|سینه پرور سلطان}}
{{lang-bg|Синепервер Султан}} | house = | father = | mother = | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] (raised [[Orthodox Christian]]) }} '''Sineperver Sultan''' ({{lang-ota|سینه پرور سلطان}}; {{circa}} 1761 – 11 December 1828) alias '''Ayşe''' ({{lang-ota|عایشه}}) was the wife of Sultan [[Abdulhamid I]] and [[Valide Sultan]] to their son Sultan [[Mustafa IV]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]].{{cite book|author=Fanny Davis|title=The Ottoman Lady: A Social History from 1718 to 1918|year=1986|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|page=6|isbn=978-0-313-24811-5}}{{cite book|author=John Freely|title=Inside the Seraglio: private lives of the sultans in Istanbul|publisher=Penguin|year=2001|isbn=|quote=}}{{cite book|author=Leslie P. Peirce|title=The Imperial Harem: Women and Sovereignty in the Ottoman Empire|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1993|location=198 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10016-4314|pages=312|isbn=978-0-19-508677-5}}{{cite book|author=Gábor Ágoston, Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|publisher=Infobase Publishing|date=1 Jan 2009|pages=414|isbn=978-1-438-11025-7}} ==Life== Sineperver Sultan performed Valide Sultan's obligations as [[de facto]] co-ruler of the [[Ottoman Sultan]] for fourteen months from 29 May 1807 until 28 July 1808. She was responsible for his education, but Mustafa preferred to live a life of pleasure instead of focusing on his studies. Her regency culminated by the deposition of Mustafa IV as a result of an [[Ottoman coups of 1807–08|insurrection]] led by [[Alemdar Mustafa Pasha]] on 28 July 1808. She apparently fell on hard times, for she wrote Mahmud II a letter in which she asked him for a house to live in. She lived more than twenty years after the execution of [[Mustafa IV]] by order of the next Ottoman Sultan [[Mahmud II]]. She died on 11 December 1828 in [[Constantinople]]. Her burial place is located at ''The Fountain (Şadırvan) Courtyard'' of [[Eyüp Sultan Mosque]] in [[Eyüp]], [[Istanbul]].{{cite book|author=M. Çağatay Uluçay|title=Padişahların kadınları ve kızları|year=2011|publisher=Ötüken|pages=248–49|isbn=978-9-754-37840-5}} ==Issue== Together with Abdul Hamid, Sineperver had four children: * Şehzade Sultan Ahmed (8 December 1776 – 18 December 1778);{{cite book|first=Mustafa Çağatay|last=Uluçay|title=Padişahların kadınları ve kızları|publisher=Ötüken, Ankara|year=2011|pages=105-9|isbn=}} * [[Esma Sultan (daughter of Abdul Hamid I)|Esma Sultan]] (17 July 1778 – 4 June 1848),{{cite book|first=Ahmet|last=Kal'a|first2=Ahmet|last2=Tabakoğlu|title=Vakıf su defterleri|publisher=İstanbul Araştırmaları Merkezi|year=2002|pages=182|isbn=}} married 29 May 1792, Damat [[Küçük Hüseyin Pasha]] (died 8 January 1803), foster-brother of Sultan [[Selim III]]; * [[Mustafa IV]] (reigned 1807–08); * Fatma Sultan (12 December 1782 – 11 January 1786);{{cite book|first=Fikret|last=Sarıcaoğlu|title=Kendi kaleminden bir Padişahın portresi Sultan I. Abdülhamid (1774-1789)|publisher=Tatav, Tarih ve Tabiat Vakfı|year=2001|pages=17|isbn=978-9-756-59601-2}} ==See also== *[[Ottoman family tree]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-roy|tr}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Valide Sultans|Valide Sultan]]|before=[[Mihrişah Sultan]]|after=[[Nakşidil Sultan]]|years=29 May 1807 – 28 July 1808}} {{s-end}} {{Ottoman Dynasty}} {{Mothers of the Ottoman Sultans}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sine, Ayse}} [[Category:1761 births]] [[Category:1828 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century Ottoman royalty]] [[Category:19th-century Ottoman royalty]] [[Category:Slaves of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Valide sultan]] [[Category:Wives of Ottoman Sultans]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Svyatoslav Vakarchuk
Святослав Вакарчук | image = Svyatoslav-vakarchuk-2008.jpg | caption = Svyatoslav Vakarchuk in [[Moscow]],
[[Russia]] on March 21, 2008.{{#tag:ref|Following the [[2014 Russian annexation of Crimea]] [[Okean Elzy]] stopped performing in [[Russia]].https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/a-new-brand-of-ukrainian-pop-is-invading-russia-57786|group=nb}} | image_size = 180px | background = solo_singer | alias = | birth_name = Sviatoslav Ivanovych Vakarchuk | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|5|14}} | birth_place = [[Mukachevo]], [[Zakarpattia Oblast]], [[Ukrainian SSR]] (now [[Ukraine]]) | death_date = | death_place = | origin = | instrument = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | occupation = Singer | years_active = 1994–present | label = | associated_acts = [[Okean Elzy]] | website = http://www.okeanelzy.com | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Slava Vakarchuk''' ({{lang-uk|Святосла́в Іва́нович Вакарчу́к}}, born May 14, 1975) is the lead vocalist of [[Okean Elzy]], the most successful post-Soviet [[rock music|rock]] band in Ukraine. He is the son of [[Ivan Vakarchuk]], a professor of physics at [[Lviv University]] and the former Minister of Education and Science in Ukraine. He was active in supporting the [[Orange Revolution]], and is involved in many social and cultural projects. He is one of the most successful musicians in Ukraine and has a degree in [[theoretical physics]]. By the year 2016, he had released 9 studio albums together with his band, Okean Elzy: * ''[[Tam, de nas nema]]'' (There, where we aren't, 1998) * ''[[Yananebibuv (Okean Elzy album)|Ya na nebi buv]]'' (I was in heaven, 2000) * ''[[Model (Okean Elzy album)|Model]]'' (2001) * ''[[Supersymetriya (Okean Elzy album)|Supersymetriya]]'' (Supersymmetry, 2003) * ''[[Gloria (Okean Elzy album)|GLORIA]]'' (2005) * ''[[Mira (Okean Elzy album)|Mira]]'' (Measure, 2007) * ''[[Dolce Vita (Okean Elzy album)|Dolce Vita]]'' (2010) * ''[[Zemlia (Okean Elzy album)|Zemlia]]'' (Earth, 2013) * ''[[Bez mezh (Okean Elzy album)|Bez mezh]]'' (Limitless, 2016) and also one (1) acoustic album ''[[Tviy format (Okean Elzy album)|Tviy format]]'' (Your format, 2003). ==Biography== Vakarchuk was born in [[Mukachevo]], in western Ukraine, raised in a family of scientists.[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/14/world/europe/ukraine-rock-star-vakarchuk.html?rref=collection%2Fbyline%2Fandrew-e.-kramer For His Next Act, a Ukrainian Rock Star Looks to Politics], [[The New York Times]] (14 September 2018) His mother and father were both university professors of physics. His father [[Ivan Vakarchuk]] is also former [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine|Education Minister]]. [https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/business/vakarchuk-to-study-at-yale-as-third-ukrainian-fellow-386989.html Vakarchuk to study at Yale as third Ukrainian fellow], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 23, 2015) Vakarchuk founded the band [[Okean Elzy]] ("Ocean of Elza"), in 1994 as an undergraduate at [[Lviv University]]. At this university he earned a Ph.D. in the field of [[supersymmetry]]. After graduation Vakarchuk moved to [[Kiev]]. In 2005 Vakarchuk answered all questions correctly and won the grand prize (1 million [[Ukrainian hryvnia|hryvnia]]s) for the first time on the Ukrainian version of [[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]], called [[Khto khoche staty milyonerom? – Pershyi milyon]]. He donated his winnings to orphanages in Ukraine.[http://vakarchuk.com/novyny/2005/02/02/vakarchuk-trishky-pobuv-milyonerom/ ''Вакарчук трішки побув мільйонером''] In the early [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|30 September 2007 parliamentary election]] he appeared as an independent candidate on the [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]]'s list (as nr 15). In the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) he was a member of the parliamentary committee for [[freedom of speech]] questions. In early September 2008, he renounced his seat in the Verkhovna Rada due to the [[2008 Ukrainian political crisis|political situation]].{{cite news |url=http://www.gazeta.ru/news/lenta/2008/09/11/n_1269306.shtml |title=Солист "Океана Эльзы" отказался от депутатского мандата |publisher=[[Gazeta.ru]] |date=2008-09-11 |accessdate=2008-09-11 |last= |first= }} Vakarchuk was a member of the parliamentary committee for [[freedom of speech in Ukraine|freedom of speech]] questions. He was also a member of groups of parliamentary contacts with Russian Federation and other countries.{{Cite web|url=http://itd.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/11120/7|title=Офіційний портал Верховної Ради України|website=itd.rada.gov.ua|access-date=2018-04-06}} Vakarchuk did not submit any legislative acts during his deputy's term. He submitted two amendments, one of which was accepted by the Verkhovna Rada.{{Cite web|url=http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/pt2/reports.dep2?PERSON=11120&SKL=7|title=Офіційний портал Верховної Ради України|website=w1.c1.rada.gov.ua|access-date=2018-04-06}} On December 16, 2008, the Verkhovna Rada accepted Vakarchuk's renunciation from his seat in the parliament due to his personal motion.{{Cite web|url=http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/664-17|title=Про дострокове припинення повноважень народного депутата У... {{!}} від 16.12.2008 № 664-VI|website=zakon.rada.gov.ua|access-date=2018-04-06}} According to Vakarchuk he renounced his parliamentary seat becuase “I was really frustrated by the level of mutual fights, at the absurd [[Hobbesian]] world of all against all, rather than changing the country for the better.” In 2008, Svyatoslav Vakarchuk released a solo project "[[Vnochi (music album)|Vnochi]]" (In the Night). This album was released under the name of Svyatoslav Vakarchuk, but it includes appearances by all members of "[[Okean Elzy]]" and other various guest musicians. Another solo project followed in 2011, "[[Brussel (music album)|Brussel]]" (Brussels). In support of their latest album "Zemlya" in spring 2013, the band embarked on a stadium tour throughout cities in Ukraine, Russia, Belarus, USA, Canada, and a number of countries in Western Europe. In December 2013 Okean Elzy performed during [[Euromaidan]]-protests.[http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/ukraine-suspends-mayor-security-official-over-protest-crackdown_896844.html Ukraine suspends mayor, security official over protest crackdown], [[Zee News]] (14 December 2013) In the summer of 2014, Okean Elzy performed a number of large scale concerts in the biggest stadiums in Ukraine dedicated to the band's 20th anniversary. Their performance in Kiev's [[Olimpiyskiy National Sports Complex|Olympiyskiy Stadium]] broken the record for the largest number of people attending a concert by a Ukrainian band — over 75 thousand. In 2015 Vakarchuk took part in the [[Yale World Fellows]] international fellowship program at [[Yale University]]. Vakarchuk stated multiple times in 2017 that he had no political ambitions.[http://m.expres.ua/#!/n/259102 President Vakarchuk: The musician spoke about political ambitions], [[Ekspres]] (26 August 2017) {{uk icon}}
[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2017/12/10/7165015/ Vakarchuk broke away from political ambitions, but called 10 points for Ukraine's development], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (10 December 2017) {{uk icon}}. However, in 2018 he joined [[Stanford University]] as a visiting scholar{{Cite web|url=http://www.okeanelzy.com/en/news/437/|title=Sviatoslav Vakarchuk joins Stanford as a visiting scholar this fall|website=www.okeanelzy.com|access-date=2018-09-18}}, focusing on politics and leadership. Later that year he appeared at several political-themed conferences, speaking alongside established Ukrainian politicians {{Cite web|url=https://yes-ukraine.org/en/news/vladu-v-ukrayini-mayut-vzyati-lyudi-yakim-doviryaye-suspilstvo-svyatoslav-vakarchuk|title=Vakarchuk presents at Yalta YES conference|website=yes-ukraine.org|access-date=2018-09-18}}. This led public to view him as a potential candidate for the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2019|2019 Ukrainian presidential election]], where he is one of the frontrunners according to the [[Opinion polling for the Ukrainian presidential election, 2019|opinion polls]]. Vakarchuk also takes an active part in social and cultural projects, and is the founder of the Charity Fund "Lyudi Maybutnyogo" (People of the Future). The main projects of the Fund were "Knyga Tvoryt' Lyudynu" (A Book Creates A Man), "Osvita Krainoyu" (The Country's Education), "3-D Proekt. Dumay, Diy, Dopomogai." (3-D Project. Think, Act. Help.). Together with the members of the band he actively supported the preventive campaign IOM and MTV Europe's "People Are Not For Sale." In 2003 Svyatoslav had become an Honorary Ambassador of Culture in Ukraine. In 2005 he became a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations Development Programme. The Ukrainian magazine ''[[Korrespondent]]'' ranks him as one of the 100 most influential people of Ukraine (in 2008 ranked 55).Korrespondent 2008-08-22, nr 32. Svyatoslav Vakarchuk speaks [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[English language|English]] and [[Polish language|Polish]] fluently. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{en icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20130126082828/http://www.okeanelzy.com/en/oe/m1 Biography at Okean Elzy official site] {{commons category|Svyatoslav Vakarchuk}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vakarchuk, Svyatoslav}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Mukacheve]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language singers]] [[Category:Ukrainian male singers]] [[Category:Ukrainian rock singers]] [[Category:Sixth convocation members of the Verkhovna Rada]] [[Category:Independent politicians of Our Ukraine Bloc]] [[Category:People of the Euromaidan]] [[Category:21st-century Ukrainian politicians]]

{{about||the film featuring Charlie Chaplin's character of the same name|The Tramp (film)|the song|The Tramp (song)}}
{{Infobox character | name = The Tramp | image = [[File:Charlie Chaplin.jpg|frameless|220px|alt=Chaplin in his costume as "the Tramp"]] | caption = Charlie Chaplin as "the Tramp". | series = | creator = [[Charlie Chaplin]] | portrayer = Charlie Chaplin | gender = Male | first = ''[[Kid Auto Races at Venice]]'' | last = ''[[Modern Times (film)|Modern Times]]''<ref>http://www.charliechaplin.com/en/biography/articles/6-Modern-Times</ref> }}
'''The Tramp''' (''Charlot'' in several languages), also known as '''The Little Tramp''', was British actor [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s most memorable on-screen character and an icon in [[world cinema]] during the era of [[silent film]]. ''[[The Tramp (film)|The Tramp]]'' is also the title of a silent film starring Chaplin, which Chaplin wrote and directed in 1915.
The Tramp, as portrayed by Chaplin, is a childlike, bumbling but generally good-hearted character who is most famously portrayed as a [[Vagrancy (people)|vagrant]] who endeavors to behave with the manners and dignity of a gentleman despite his actual social status. However, while he is ready to take what paying work is available, he also uses his cunning to get what he needs to survive and escape the authority figures who will not tolerate his antics. Chaplin's films did not always portray the Tramp as a vagrant, however. The character ("The little fellow," as Chaplin called him) was rarely referred to by any names on-screen, although he was sometimes identified as "Charlie" and rarely, as in the original silent version of ''[[The Gold Rush]]'', "The little funny tramp".
==History== {{refimprove|section|date=February 2018}}<!--3 paragraphs have no citations--> [[File:Mabel's Strange Predicament (1914).webm|thumb|thumbtime=1|upright=1.5|''[[Mabel's Strange Predicament]]'', the first film produced in which Chaplin plays the Tramp]] [[File:Chaplin - Kid Auto Races in Venice.png|thumb|right|''[[Kid Auto Races at Venice]]'' was the first appearance of the Tramp released but actually the second film shot.]] [[File:Charlie Chaplin circa 1916.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Chaplin in 1916]] The character of the Tramp was originally created by accident while Chaplin was working at [[Mack Sennett]]'s [[Keystone Studios]], when dressing up for the short film ''[[Mabel's Strange Predicament]]'' starring [[Mabel Normand]] and Chaplin. In a 1933 interview, Chaplin explained how he came up with the look of the Tramp:<ref>{{citation |title=A Comedian Sees the World |author=Charlie Chaplin |journal=[[Woman's Home Companion]] |date=November 1933}}</ref> {{quote|A hotel set was built for (fellow Keystone comic) [[Mabel Normand]]'s picture ''[[Mabel's Strange Predicament]]'' and I was hurriedly told to put on a funny make-up. This time I went to the wardrobe and got a pair of baggy pants, a tight coat, a small derby hat and a large pair of shoes. I wanted the clothes to be a mass of contradictions, knowing pictorially the figure would be vividly outlined on the screen. To add a comic touch, I wore a small mustache which would not hide my expression. My appearance got an enthusiastic response from everyone, including Mr. Sennett. The clothes seemed to imbue me with the spirit of the character. He actually became a man with a soul—a point of view. I defined to Mr. Sennett the type of person he was. He wears an air of romantic hunger, forever seeking romance, but his feet won't let him.}} That was actually the first film featuring the Tramp but a different film, shot later but with the same character, happened to be released two days earlier. The Tramp debuted to the public in the [[Keystone Studios|Keystone]] [[comedy film|comedy]] ''[[Kid Auto Races at Venice]]'' (released on February 7, [[1914 in film|1914]]; ''Mabel's Strange Predicament'', shot earlier, was released on February 9, 1914). Chaplin, with his Little Tramp character, quickly became the most popular star in Keystone director [[Mack Sennett]]'s company of players. Chaplin continued to play the Tramp through dozens of short films and, later, feature-length productions. (In only a handful of other productions did he play characters other than the Tramp).
The Tramp was closely identified with the silent era, and was considered an international character. When the [[sound film|sound]] era began in the late 1920s, Chaplin refused to make a [[talkie]] featuring the character, partly due to how the character was supposed to be American, and Chaplin himself had a strong and obvious British accent. The 1931 production ''[[City Lights]]'' featured no dialogue. Chaplin officially retired the character in the film ''[[Modern Times (film)|Modern Times]]'' (released February 5, [[1936 in film|1936]]), which appropriately ended with the Tramp walking down an endless highway toward the horizon. The film was only a partial talkie and is often called the last silent film. The Tramp remains silent until near the end of the film when, for the first time, his voice is finally heard, albeit only as part of a French/Italian-derived gibberish song. This allowed the Tramp to finally be given a voice but not tarnish his association with the silent era.
In ''[[The Great Dictator]]'', Chaplin's first film after ''Modern Times'', Chaplin plays the dual role of a [[Hitler]]-esque dictator, and a Jewish barber. Although Chaplin emphatically stated that the barber was not the Tramp, he retains the Tramp's moustache, hat, and general appearance. Despite a few silent scenes, including one where the barber is wearing the Tramp's coat and bowler hat and carrying his cane, the barber speaks throughout the film (using Chaplin's own British accent), including the passionate plea for peace that has been widely interpreted as Chaplin speaking as himself.
In 1959, having been editing ''The Chaplin Revue'', Chaplin commented to a reporter (regarding the Tramp character) "I was wrong to kill him. There was room for the Little Man in the atomic age."<ref>{{citation |title=Chaplin: His Life And Art |page=137 |isbn=0141979186 |author=David Robinson |year=2014}}</ref>
A [[vaudeville]] performer named [[Lew Bloom]] created a similar tramp character which inspired Chaplin. According to Bloom, he was "the first stage tramp in the business".<ref>{{citation |last=DePastino |first=Todd |title=Citizen Hobo: How a Century of Homelessness Shaped America |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2003 |page=157}}</ref>
== Characteristics == [[File:The Tramp (film).jpg|thumb|left|The Tramp on the road.]] The physical attributes of the Tramp include a pair of baggy pants, a tight coat, a small [[bowler hat]], a large pair of shoes, a springy and flexible cane and the [[Toothbrush moustache|famous small mustache]]. The Tramp walks strangely and uncomfortably because of the ill-fitting clothing; either he is wearing secondhand clothes, or they are originally his but he cannot afford new ones. The Tramp may have seen better days, but he maintains the attitude and demeanor of a high-class individual; as long as he acts like one he can believe that he is one, and is able to keep his hope that some day he actually will be again.
Two films made in 1915, ''[[The Tramp (film)|The Tramp]]'' and ''[[The Bank (1915 film)|The Bank]]'', created the characteristics of Chaplin's screen persona. While in the end the Tramp manages to shake off his disappointment and resume his carefree ways, the pathos lies in the Tramp's having a hope for a more permanent transformation through love, and his failure to achieve this.<ref>{{citation|first=Christian |last=Hansmeyer |year=2007 |title=Charlie Chaplin's Techniques for the Creation of Comic Effect in His Films |page=4}}</ref>
The Tramp was usually the victim of circumstance and coincidence, but sometimes the results worked in his favor. In ''Modern Times'', he picks up a [[Red flag (politics)|red flag]] that falls off a truck and starts to wave it at the truck in an attempt to return it, and by doing so, unknowingly and inadvertently becomes the leader of a group of protesting workers, and ends up in jail because of it. While in jail he accidentally eats “nose powder” (i.e., [[cocaine]]), which causes him to not return to his jail cell; but when he eventually does, he fights off some jailbreakers attempting to escape, thus saving the life of the warden. Because of this, the warden offers to let him go, but the Tramp would rather stay in jail because it is better than the outside world.
==Significance== [[File:Chaplin A Dogs Life.jpg|thumb|''[[A Dog's Life]]'' (1918)]] Chaplin's social commentary, while critical of the faults and excesses created by [[industrialization]], also shows support for and belief in the “American Dream." In ''Modern Times'', Chaplin creates a “portrayal consistent with popular [[left-wing politics|leftist]] stereotypes of wealthy union leaders and oppressed workers in the 1930s.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=151}} While the Tramp and his fellow workers sweat on the assembly line, the president of the Electro Steel Company works on a puzzle and reads the funnies in the newspaper. The obsession of working with efficiency and assembly-line productivity ultimately drives the Tramp mad. This could be seen as “an attack on the capitalist rationalization of production.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=152}} However, “the film also guardedly affirms American middle-class, particularly its optimism.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=153}} For example, one sequence depicts the Tramp's dream in which he and the [[gamine]] live a traditional middle-class lifestyle.
The Tramp and the gamine find a rundown shack to live in. The gamine cooks a cheap breakfast, and then the Tramp is off to work, while the gamine stays to maintain the home—an allusion to a middle-class setting. By the ending of ''Modern Times'', “the film seems tailored to please the middle-class optimist.” Due to all of their failings the final scene had the gamine stating, “What's the use of trying?”, and the Tramp replying “Buck up—never say die.” In his silent films, Chaplin uniquely deployed critical social commentary. “What makes ''Modern Times'' decidedly different from Chaplin's previous three films are the political references and social realism that keep intruding into Charlie's world.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=150}} “No comedian before or after him has spent more energy depicting people in their working lives.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=110}} “Though there had been films depicting the lives of immigrants and urban workers, no filmmaker before Chaplin had created their experience so humanly and lovingly.”{{sfn|Maland|1991|p=113}}
Chaplin used not one but two similar-looking characters to the Tramp in ''[[The Great Dictator]]'' (released October 15, 1940); however, this was an all-talking film (Chaplin's first). The film was inspired by the noted similarity between Chaplin's Tramp (most notably his small mustache) and that of [[Nazi Germany|German]] dictator [[Adolf Hitler]]. Chaplin used this similarity to create a dark version of the Tramp character in parody of the dictator. (In his book ''[[My Autobiography (Chaplin)|My Autobiography]]'', Chaplin stated that he was unaware of [[the Holocaust]] when he made the film; if he had been, he writes, he wouldn't have been able to make a comedy satirizing Hitler). In his autobiography, Chaplin identifies the barber as the Tramp. A noticeable difference is that the barber has a streak of grey in his hair, whereas the Tramp had always been depicted as having dark hair. Also, the barber lacks the ill-fitting clothes of the Tramp, and is clearly portrayed as having a profession. His character does share much of The Tramp's character, notably his idealism and anger on seeing unfairness.
==The short film== ''[[The Tramp (film)|The Tramp]]'' is also a short film starring Chaplin as the titular main character. In the film, a hobo exchanges the Tramp's sandwich for a brick, so the Tramp must eat grass. The same hobo later bothers a farmer's daughter, and the Tramp comes to her aid with the help of the brick. When two more hobos show up, the Tramp throws all three into a lake. The grateful girl takes the Tramp home, where he fails as a farmhand. He again helps drive off the hobos (who are now trying to break into the house). The girl's fiancé arrives. Though a hero, Charlie—knowing he must go—writes a farewell note and leaves again for the open road.
The film also stars [[Edna Purviance]], [[Lloyd Bacon]], and Leo White.
''The Tramp'' was released on April 11, 1915, through [[Essanay Studios]].
==Legacy== *Numerous works cite the Tramp as an icon of the [[Great Depression]], of [[Charlie Chaplin]] himself, and of the downtrodden hero, from Chaplin's own movies with similar characters (such as ''The Great Dictator''), to the dapper, silent penguin rescued by [[Bugs Bunny]]. *In the 1980s, the character was portrayed in advertising for the [[IBM PC]] [[personal computer]].<ref>Caputi, Jane (1994). [http://xroads.virginia.edu/~DRBR/caputi.html "IBM's Charlie Chaplin: A Case Study"]. ''Signs of Life in the U.S.A.: Readings on Popular Culture for Writers''. (Boston: Bedford Books) pp.117-121. Archived at [[University of Virginia]].</ref><ref>Papson, Stephen (April 1990). [http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/onlinessays/JC35folder/IBMtramp.html "The IBM tramp"]. ''[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]'', no. 35, pp. 66-72.</ref> *The cartoon character "[[Baggy Pants and the Nitwits|Baggy Pants]]" presents an imitation of the Tramp. *From 1973 to 1990, the children's educational television series ''[[Sesame Street]]'' occasionally featured cast member [[Sonia Manzano]] in character as the Tramp for some skits.

{{mergefrom|Tom Harrell Quintet|discuss=Talk:Tom Harrell#Merger proposal|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Tom Harrell | image = Tom Harrell 2011.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Harrell performing in 2011 | landscape = yes | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|6|16|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Urbana, Illinois]], U.S. | genre = [[Jazz]] | occupation = Musician | instrument = Trumpet, flugelhorn | years_active = 1969–present | label = [[Contemporary Records|Contemporary]], [[Chesky Records|Chesky]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[High Note Records|High Note]] | associated_acts = [[Horace Silver]], [[Phil Woods]] | website = {{URL|tomharrell.com}} }} [[File:Tom Harrell Victoria teater Oslo Jazzfestival (181605).jpg|thumb|Tom Harrell at the 2017 Oslo Jazz Festival]] '''Tom Harrell''' (born June 16, 1946) is an American [[jazz]] trumpeter, flugelhornist, composer, and arranger. Harrell has won awards and grants, including multiple Trumpeter of the Year awards from ''[[Down Beat]]'' magazine,<ref name="th-la-times1999">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/dec/04/entertainment/ca-40252|title=Tom Harrell Goes the Big-Band Rout|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=December 4, 1999|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728161334/http://articles.latimes.com/1999/dec/04/entertainment/ca-40252|archivedate=July 28, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> [[SESAC]] Jazz Award, BMI ([[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]) Composers Award, and Prix Oscar du Jazz. He received a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for his big band album, ''[[Time's Mirror]]''.
==Biography== Tom Harrell was born in [[Urbana, Illinois]] but moved to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] at the age of five. He started playing trumpet at eight, and within five years he was playing gigs with local bands. In 1969 he graduated from [[Stanford University]] with a music composition degree and joined [[Stan Kenton]]'s orchestra, touring and recording with them throughout 1969.<ref name="th-aaj-profile">{{cite web|url=http://musicians.allaboutjazz.com/musician.php?id=7432|title=Musician Profile: Tom Harrell|publisher=All About Jazz|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213083139/http://musicians.allaboutjazz.com/musician.php?id=7432|archivedate=December 13, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="th-notjazz-blog">{{cite web|url=http://notoriousjazz.com/era/1941-1960/daily-dose-of-jazz-896|title=Daily Dose of Jazz… Tom Harrell|publisher=notorious jazz blog|accessdate=September 1, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140902022222/http://notoriousjazz.com/era/1941-1960/daily-dose-of-jazz-896|archivedate=September 2, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
After leaving Kenton, Harrell played with [[Woody Herman]]'s big band (1970–1971), [[Azteca (band)|Azteca]] (1972), the [[Horace Silver]] Quintet (1973–1977), with whom he made five albums, the [[Samuel Jones (musician)|Sam Jones]]-Tom Harrell Big Band, the [[Lee Konitz]] Nonet (1979–1981), [[George Russell (composer)|George Russell]], and the [[Mel Lewis]] Orchestra (1981). From 1983 to 1989 he was a pivotal member of the [[Phil Woods]] Quintet and made seven albums with the group. In addition, he recorded albums with [[Vince Guaraldi]] for whom he also did some arranging for the [[Peanuts]] television specials, [[Bill Evans]], [[Dizzy Gillespie]], [[Ronnie Cuber]], [[Bob Brookmeyer]], [[Lionel Hampton]], [[Bob Berg]], [[Cecil Payne]], [[Bobby Shew]], [[Philip Catherine]], {{Interlanguage link multi|Ivan Paduart|fr}}, [[Joe Lovano]], [[Charlie Haden]]'s Liberation Orchestra, [[Charles McPherson (musician)|Charles McPherson]], [[David Sánchez (musician)|David Sánchez]], [[Sheila Jordan]], [[Jane Monheit]], the [[King's Singers]] and [[Kathleen Battle]] among others.<ref name="th-aaj-profile" /><ref name="th-notjazz-blog" /><ref name="th-am-bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tom-harrell-mn0000605535/biography|title=Allmusic: Tom Harrell - Biography|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=September 1, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query.php|archivedate=July 29, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="th-aaj-fireside">{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=842&page=1|title=Interview: A Fireside Chat With Tom Harrell|publisher=All About Jazz|date=November 14, 2003|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019103400/http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=842&page=1|archivedate=October 19, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> Harrell is featured on Bill Evans' final studio recording, ''[[We Will Meet Again]]'', which won a Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Jazz Performance, Group.<ref name="th-grammy1981">{{cite web|url=http://www.awardsandshows.com/features/grammy-awards-1981-229.html|title=Awards & Shows – Grammy Awards 1981|publisher=awardsandshows.com|accessdate=August 3, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021164628/http://www.awardsandshows.com/features/grammy-awards-1981-229.html|archivedate=October 21, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
While Harrell recorded several albums as a leader during his tenure with the Phil Woods Quintet, it was after his departure that he started producing albums as a leader, in succession for [[Contemporary Records]] (now owned by [[Concord Records|Concord]]), [[Chesky Records|Chesky]], and RCA/BMG. During his years as a [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]] artist (1996–2003) first with [[RCA Records|RCA]], then [[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]] and finally [[Arista Records|Arista]], Harrell made six albums, many of which feature his arrangements for larger groups. Since the early 1990s, Harrell has toured and performed with his own groups of various sizes and instrumentation.<ref name="th-aaj-profile" /><ref name="th-am-bio" />
Harrell is a prolific arranger and composer. He has arranged for [[Vince Guaraldi]]'s work on ''Peanuts'', [[Carlos Santana]], the [[Metropole Orchestra]], the [[DR Big Band|Danish Radio Big Band]], the [[Vanguard Jazz Orchestra]], and Elisabeth Kontomanou with the {{Interlanguage link multi|Orchestre National de Lorraine|fr}}, among others. His compositions have been recorded by other jazz artists including [[Ron Carter]], [[Kenny Barron]], [[Art Farmer]], [[Chris Potter (jazz saxophonist)|Chris Potter]], [[Tom Scott (musician)|Tom Scott]], [[Steve Kuhn]], [[Kenny Werner]] and [[Hank Jones]]. Harrell's composition and big band arrangement entitled "Humility" was recorded on the [[Grammy]]-winning album by [[Arturo O'Farrill]]'s Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra, ''[[Song for Chico]]''. As a composer and arranger, Harrell works in different genres, including classical music.<ref name="th-aaj-profile" /><ref name="th-notjazz-blog" /><ref name="th-jazztimes-bio">{{cite web|url=http://jazztimes.com/articles/21089-tom-harrell-senses-and-sensibilities|title=Tom Harrell: Senses and Sensibilities|publisher=JazzTimes|date=May 1998 |author=Bill Milkowski|accessdate=July 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150720004415/http://jazztimes.com/articles/21089-tom-harrell-senses-and-sensibilities|archivedate=July 20, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Tom Harrell Quintet== Since 1989 Harrell has led his own groups, usually quintets but occasionally expanded ensembles such as chamber orchestras with strings, and big bands. He has appeared at most major jazz clubs and festival venues, and recorded under his own name for such record labels as [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Contemporary Records|Contemporary]], Pinnacle, Blackhawk, [[Criss Cross Jazz|Criss Cross]], [[SteepleChase]], [[Chesky Records|Chesky]], and [[HighNote Records|HighNote]].<ref name="th-notjazz-blog" />
In contrast to his signature recordings during the [[RCA Records|RCA]]/[[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]] years (1996–2003), where much of his focus was on projects involving large ensembles, big bands and chamber orchestras, Harrell's more recent works demonstrate his skills as a leader of a tight, smaller unit. Harrell has made four albums with the current quintet of six years, which comprises tenor saxophonist [[Wayne Escoffery]], pianist [[Danny Grissett]], bassist [[Ugonna Okegwo]] who has performed with Harrell since 1997, and drummer Johnathan Blake.<ref name="th-aaj-profile" /><ref name="th-roman-nights">{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=36196|title=Tom Harrell: Roman Nights (2010)|publisher=All About Jazz|date=April 18, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014085403/http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=36196|archivedate=October 14, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> The group is noted for the strong chemistry between the musicians and the distinctive sound achieved primarily through Harrell's compositions.<ref name="th-irish-times">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2010/0709/1224274309183.html|title=Tom Harrell - Roman Nights|publisher=The Irish Times|date=July 7, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812230050/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2010/0709/1224274309183.html|archivedate=August 12, 2011|deadurl=no|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="th-audiophile">{{cite web|url=http://audaud.com/2010/05/tom-harrell-roman-nights-high-note/|title=Tom Harrell - Roma Nights - High Note|publisher=Audiophile Audition|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228091655/http://audaud.com/2010/05/tom-harrell-roman-nights-high-note/|archivedate=December 28, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> Harrell's current quintet differs from previous editions of quintets he has formed and worked with, in the use of Fender Rhodes and acoustic piano.<ref name="th-jazziz2010">{{cite web|url= http://www.jazziz.com/uploads/May2010/pageflip.html|title=22 May, 2010 ROMAN NIGHTS - Jazziz review|publisher=jazziz.com and tomharrell.com|date=May 22, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413125516/http://www.tomharrell.com/html/news.php|archivedate=April 13, 2013|deadurl=yes <!--archived from, http://www.tomharrell.com/html/news.php -->}}</ref> Harrell's 2012 recording, ''[[Number Five (album)|Number Five]]'', received his seventh [[SESAC]] Jazz Award.<ref name="th-sesac-awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.sesac.com/News/News_Details.aspx?id=1670|title= SESAC Honors Music Greats at 8th Annual Jazz Awards Luncheon|publisher=SESAC|date=March 9, 2012|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728154533/http://www.sesac.com/News/News_Details.aspx?id=1670|archivedate=July 28, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Tom Harrell Chamber Ensemble== In June 2012, Harrell debuted his nine-piece chamber ensemble at the Highline Ballroom as part of the [[Blue Note Jazz Festival]]. Harrell arranged the music of [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]], [[Maurice Ravel|Ravel]], and his own compositions for this ensemble, which consists of trumpet, soprano and tenor saxophones, c-flute and bass flute, violin, cello, acoustic guitar, piano, bass, and drums.<ref name="th-aaj-profile" /><ref name="th-daily-news2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/nyc-style-jazz-meets-classical-music-muses-trumpeter-tom-harrell-article-1.981270|title=NYC-style jazz meets classical music|location=New York|work=Daily News|date=November 27, 2011|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119050022/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/nyc-style-jazz-meets-classical-music-muses-trumpeter-tom-harrell-article-1.981270|archivedate=November 19, 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref> The Tom Harrell Chamber Ensemble has since performed at the Village Vanguard, Autumn Jazz Festival in Bielsko Biala, the Jazz Standard, the Xerox Rochester International Jazz Festival, the Scripps Auditorium in San Diego, and Soka University Performing Arts Center in Aliso Viejo, CA. Harrell considers the arrangements and compositions some of the most challenging works he has written to date.<ref name="th-daily-news2011" /><ref name="th-xerox-2012">{{cite web|url=http://sanjose.jazznearyou.com/event_detail.php?id=461254|title=Tom Harrell Chamber Ensemble at Xerox Rochester International Jazz Festival|publisher=jazznearyou.com|accessdate=October 26, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027012423/http://sanjose.jazznearyou.com/event_detail.php?id=461254|archivedate=October 27, 2014|deadurl=yes}}</ref>{{Additional citation needed|date=July 2015}}
==''Colors of a Dream''== In 2013, Harrell formed a piano-less sextet with two basses called ''Colors of a Dream'', which comprises himself on trumpet and flugelhorn, [[Wayne Escoffery]] on tenor saxophone, [[Jaleel Shaw]] on alto saxophone, Johnathan Blake on drums, [[Ugonna Okegwo]] on bass and [[Esperanza Spalding]] doubling on bass and vocal. The group debuted at the [[Village Vanguard]] during its six-night run starting March 26, 2013 and the second night's performance was webcast for live streaming by [[NPR]].<ref name="th-npr2013">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/174986548/tom-harrells-colors-of-a-dream-live-at-the-village-vanguard|title=Tom Harrell's 'Colors Of A Dream': Live At The Village Vanguard|publisher=NPR.org|date=March 27, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110052603/http://www.npr.org/event/music/174986548/tom-harrells-colors-of-a-dream-live-at-the-village-vanguard|archivedate=January 10, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="th-db2014" /> A studio album by the same name was released on October 22, 2013 for which Harrell received his eighth [[SESAC]] Jazz Awards the following year.<ref name="SESAC News">{{cite web|title=SESAC Honors Music Greats at 9th Annual Jazz Awards Luncheon|url=http://www.sesac.com/News/News_Details.aspx?id=2140|website=www.sesac.com|accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="th-allmusic-colors">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/colors-of-a-dream-mw0002579683|title=Allmusic: Tom Harrell - Colors of a Dream - overview|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qh7Izo8v?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/colors-of-a-dream-mw0002579683|archivedate=June 29, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
==TRIP== Harrell also recorded with TRIP, a piano-less quartet featuring saxophonist [[Mark Turner (musician)|Mark Turner]], bassist Ugonna Okegwo and drummer Adam Cruz in 2013. The group first performed in Rochester, New York, and at the Jazz Standard during [[Dave Douglas (trumpeter)|Dave Douglas]]' Festival of New Trumpet Music (FONT) in October 2012. Harrell premiered the suite with six sections he wrote specifically for this group. TRIP reconvened a year later at the [[Village Vanguard]] and made a studio recording the following week.<ref name="th-db2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.downbeat.com/digitaledition/2014/DB1401/_art/DB1401.pdf|author=Phillip Lutz|title=Tom Harrell 'Magic Can Happen Anytime'|publisher=[[Down Beat|DownBeat Magazine]]|date=January 2014|pages=34–38|accessdate=June 29, 2014}}</ref><ref name="th-trip-roch-2012">{{cite web|url=http://exodustojazz.com/tom-harrell-quartet/|title=Rochester, NY: Exodus To Jazz presents Tom Harrell|publisher=exodustojazz.com|accessdate=October 26, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111002817/http://exodustojazz.com/tom-harrell-quartet/|archivedate=January 11, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> The quartet released the self-titled album ''TRIP'' on August 12, 2014.<ref name="th-trip-am">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/trip-mw0002701860|title=Allmusic: Tom Harrell – Trip|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=August 26, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S8565LKN?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/trip-mw0002701860|archivedate=August 27, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
==Publications== Harrell's work as composer and jazz soloist has been published in books by [[Hal Leonard]],<ref name="th-halleonard">{{cite web|url=http://www.halleonard.com/product/viewproduct.do?itemid=672382&lid=110&seriesfeature=ARTTRN&|title=Tom Harrel - Jazz Trumpet Solos Collection|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728195041/http://www.halleonard.com/product/viewproduct.do?itemid=672382&lid=110&seriesfeature=ARTTRN&|archivedate=July 28, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> [[Jamey Aebersold]],<ref name="th-vol63-jazzbooks">{{cite web|url=http://www.jazzbooks.com/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=JAJAZZ&Product_Code=V63DS&Category_Code=|title=Volume 63 - Tom Harrell|publisher=Jazzbooks.com|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728202341/http://www.jazzbooks.com/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=JAJAZZ&Product_Code=V63DS&Category_Code=|archivedate=July 28, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> Sher Music,<ref name="th-real-book">{{cite web|url=http://www.shermusic.com/new/1883217148.shtml|title=The All-Jazz Real Book|publisher=Sher Music Co|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109192641/http://www.shermusic.com/new/1883217148.shtml|archivedate=January 9, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>http://www.trumpetspot.com/1060474.html {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829133331/http://www.trumpetspot.com/1060474.html |date=August 29, 2008 }}</ref> and Gerard and Sarzin.<ref name="th-ahead-jazzbook">{{cite web|url=http://www.changingtones.com/gerandsz/fakbok.html|title=Straight Ahead Jazz Fakebook|publisher=Gerard and Sarzin Publishing Co|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020193342/http://www.changingtones.com/gerandsz/fakbok.html|archivedate=October 20, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Discography==
=== As leader === * ''Aurora'' (1976, reissued as ''Total'', 1987) * ''Mind's Ear'' (1978) * ''Play of Light'' ([[Palo Alto Records|Palo Alto]], 1984) * ''Moon Alley'' ([[Criss Cross Records|Criss Cross]], 1985) * ''Sundance'' (1986)<!-- primary artist with George Robert --> * ''Open Air'' ([[SteepleChase Records|SteepleChase]], 1987) * ''Stories'' ([[Contemporary Records|Contemporary]], 1988) * ''Lonely Eyes'' ([[GRP Records|GRP]], 1989)<!-- primary artist with George Robert --> * ''Sail Away'' (Contemporary,1989) * ''Form'' (Contemporary, 1990) * ''Moon and Sand'' (Jazz Aux Remparts, 1991) <!-- primary artist with Jacky Terrasson --> * ''Visions'' (Contemporary, 1991) * ''Passages'' ([[Chesky Records|Chesky]], 1991) * ''Sail Away'' ([[Musidisc]], 1992) * ''Upswing'' (Chesky, 1994) * ''Cape Verde'' (Mons, 1995) <!-- primary artist with George Robert --> * ''Labyrinth'' ([[RCA Victor]], 1996) * ''The Art of Rhythm'' (RCA Victor, 1998) * ''[[Time's Mirror]]'' (RCA Victor, 1999) * ''Paradise'' (RCA Victor, 2001) * ''[[Live at the Village Vanguard (Tom Harrell album)|Live at the Village Vanguard]]'' ([[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]], 2002) * ''Wise Children'' (Bluebird, 2003) * ''[[Light On (album)|Light On]]'' ([[HighNote Records|HighNote]], 2007) * ''[[Prana Dance]]'' (HighNote, 2009) * ''[[Roman Nights]]'' (HighNote, 2010) * ''[[The Time of the Sun]]'' (HighNote, 2011) * ''[[Number Five (album)|Number Five]]'' (HighNote, 2012) * ''[[Colors of a Dream]]'' (HighNote, 2013) * ''TRIP'' (HighNote, 2014) * ''First Impressions'' (HighNote, 2015) * ''Something Gold, Something Blue'' (HighNote, 2016) * ''Moving Picture'' (HighNote, 2017)
===As co-leader=== '''With [[Art Farmer]]''' *''[[The Company I Keep]]'' (Arabesque, 1994) '''With [[John McNeil (musician)|John McNeil]]''' * ''Look to the Sky'' (SteepleChase, 1979)
===As sideman=== '''With [[Gordon Brisker]]''' * ''Cornerstone'' (Sea Breeze, 1984)<ref name="th-cornerstone">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cornerstone-mw0000849757|title=Allmusic: Gordon Brisker - Cornerstone - overview|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qh7Xc7rN?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cornerstone-mw0000849757|archivedate=June 29, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
'''With [[Donald Brown (musician)|Donald Brown]]''' * ''[[People Music (Donald Brown album)|People Music]]'' (Muse, 1990) '''With [[Thomas Chapin]]''' *''[[You Don't Know Me (Thomas Chapin album)|You Don't Know Me]]'' (Arabesque, 1995) '''With [[Harold Danko]]''' * ''Coincidence'' (Dreamstreet, 1979)<ref name="th-coincidence">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/coincidence-mw0001007525|title=Allmusic: Harold Danko - Coincidence - overview|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=June 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qh7iBkY2?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/coincidence-mw0001007525|archivedate=June 29, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
'''With [[Bill Evans]]''' * ''[[We Will Meet Again]]'' ([[Verve Records|Verve]], 1979) '''With [[George Gruntz]]''' * ''[[Theatre (album)|Theatre]]'' ([[ECM Records|ECM]], 1983) '''With [[Charlie Haden]]''' * ''[[Dream Keeper]]'' (Verve, 1990) * ''[[The Montreal Tapes: Liberation Music Orchestra]]'' (Verve, 1999) '''With [[Lee Konitz]]''' * ''[[Yes, Yes, Nonet]]'' (SteepleChase, 1979) '''With [[Joe Lovano]]''' * ''[[Village Rhythm]]'' ([[Soul Note]], 1988) * ''[[Quartets: Live at the Village Vanguard]]'' ([[Blue Note Records|Blue Note]], 1994) '''With [[Charles McPherson (musician)|Charles McPherson]]''' *''[[First Flight Out]]'' (Araesque, 1994) '''With [[Idris Muhammad]]''' *''[[House of the Rising Sun (album)|House of the Rising Sun]]'' (Kudu, 1976) '''With [[Gerry Mulligan]]''' * ''[[Walk on the Water (album)|Walk on the Water]]'' ([[DRG Records|DRG]], 1980) '''With [[Cecil Payne]]''' * ''[[Bird Gets the Worm (album)|Bird Gets the Worm]]'' ([[Muse Records|Muse]], 1976) '''With [[Horace Silver]]''' * ''[[Silver 'n Brass]]'' (Blue Note, 1975)<ref>Blue Note LP BN-LA406G, 1975</ref> * ''[[Silver 'n Wood]]'' (Blue Note, 1976) * ''[[Silver 'n Voices]]'' (Blue Note, 1976) * ''[[Silver 'n Percussion]]'' (Blue Note, 1977) * ''[[Silver 'n Strings Play the Music of the Spheres]]'' (Blue Note, 1979) '''With [[Jim Hall (musician)|Jim Hall]]''' * ''[[These Rooms]]'' (DENON/Nippon Columbia, 1988) '''With [[Steve Swallow]]''' * ''[[Real Book (album)|Real Book]]'' (Xtra Watt, 1993) '''With [[Phil Woods]]''' * ''Integrity'' ([[Red Records|Red]], 1984)<ref name="th-am-credits">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tom-harrell-mn0000605535/credits|title=Allmusic: Tom Harrell - Credits|publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=September 4, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6SLlvhgY7?url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tom-harrell-mn0000605535/credits|archivedate=September 5, 2014|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> * ''Gratitude'' ([[Denon Records|Denon]], 1986) * ''[[Dizzy Gillespie Meets Phil Woods Quintet]]'' ([[Timeless Records|Timeless]], 1986) * ''Bop Stew'' ([[Concord Records|Concord]], 1987) * ''Evolution'' (Concord, 1988) * ''Flash'' (Concord, 1989) * ''Bouquet'' (Concord, 1989)
